The speeches read as follows-
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1987 [No. 2]

Mr President, this Bill is the first in a package of four Bills that will give effect to the Government's decision to introduce a petroleum resource rent tax on profits from certain off-shore petroleum projects.
The proposed tax regime was announced in detail in June 1984, after extensive consultation with the industry and the States.
These Bills are now being reintroduced in the same form in which they were before the Senate when Parliament was dissolved for the election and the Bills consequently lapsed.

Petroleum resources are, in their most basic sense, community property and the Government believes that the community as a whole should share in the potentially high returns from the exploitation of these scarce, non-renewable resources.

At the same time it is recognised that participants in petroleum projects who do not earn high profits in relation to the amount invested and the risk involved, particularly when oil prices decline, should be able to operate secure in the knowledge that excise and royalties which are based on production will not apply.
The Government believes that a resource rent tax related to achieved profits is a more efficient and equitable secondary taxation regime than the excise and royalty system that it is to replace.
I emphasise that the proposed tax replaces the existing system-it is not in addition to it.
In contrast to production-based secondary tax regimes, the petroleum resource rent tax will be payable only in respect of projects earning a high rate of return on outlays.
Particularly in light of the current volatility of world oil prices, the resource rent tax system thus offers considerable benefits to the petroleum industry.

It strikes a reasonable balance between the objectives of satisfying the right of the community as a whole to share in the benefits of profitable off-shore petroleum projects, and of providing the participants with adequate returns for the risks they accept in undertaking off-shore exploration and development activities.
The Bill incorporates amendments made after government consideration of representations made by the petroleum industry.
The provisions of the Bill nevertheless follow closely the proposal as announced in June 1984, while accommodating the retention lease system in relation to off-shore petroleum exploration.
Mr President, I now turn to outline the more significant features of the tax.
General Application

The tax is to apply to a person's taxable profits from the recovery of petroleum in off-shore areas where the Commonwealth's Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 applies, other than in areas covered by production licences granted on or before 1 July 1984 and the permit areas from which those production licences were drawn.
The tax will therefore not apply to the North West Shelf permit areas or Esso's and BHP's Bass Strait permit area-excise and royalty arrangements will continue to apply in those areas.

As the petroleum resource rent tax is profit-based, rather than production-based, it will apply only where there is an excess of project-related receipts for a financial year over both project-related expenditure for the year and undeducted expenditure of previous years brought forward at a compound rate.
This compounding of expenditure ensures that the investment presented by the expenditure obtains an appropriate rate of return free of secondary tax.
The rate of compounding for expenditure that remains undeducted at the end of a financial year will be determined according to when it was expended.

Expenditure (generally exploration expenditure) more than 5 years before coming into force of the first production licence in a permit area will attract compounding at a rate equal to the GDP deflator rate-currently around 8%.

More recent expenditure in respect of the project will be carried forward at a rate equal to the prevailing long term bond rate increased by 15 percentage points (currently this produces a rate of about 28 per cent).

In board terms, a petroleum project incorporates the production licence area, and such treatment and other facilities and operations outside that area as are integral to the production and initial on-site storage of marketable petroleum commodities such as stabilised crude oil, condensate and liquefied petroleum gas.

As a practical matter, two or more projects will be treated as a single project for tax purposes where the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, having regard to relevant factors, considers that they should be so treated and issues a certificate to that effect.

The boundaries of a petroleum project will not extend beyond the point at which a marketable petroleum commodity is initially stored after production-that is, the project boundaries will not extend to `downstream activities' such as refineries and facilities for the transport of marketable products from initial storage.
Assessable Receipts
Liability for petroleum resource rent tax is to be assessed on the accruals basis that generally applies in determining income tax liability.
Assessable receipts from the project will, therefore, be taken into account in the financial year in which they are receivable.
Assessable project receipts will include amounts receivable from the sale of petroleum or of a marketable petroleum commodity.

In the event that a marketable petroleum commodity is not sold after the point of initial on-site storage, the market value-or a fair and reasonable value-of the commodity will be treated as an assessable receipt of the project.
The need to attribute a value could arise, for example, in the case of an integrated producer who both extracts crude oil and refines it.
Deductible Expenditure

Expenditure of either a capital or a revenue nature which is directly related to a petroleum project will be deductible in the year in which it is incurred against any assessable receipts for the year.
Any excess of deductible expenditure (other than closing-down expenditure) over assessable receipts at the end of a year will be compounded forward for deduction against receipts in future years.
Deductible expenditure comprises exploration expenditure, general project expenditure and closing-down expenditure, subject to the exclusion of certain specific items of expenditure.

Exploration expenditure consists, broadly, of expenditure (other than excluded expenditure) in an exploration permit area that is directly related to exploration for petroleum and will include expenditure on the recovery of petroleum and the production of a marketable commodity prior to the coming into force of a production licence.
Exploration expenditure includes related expenditure on storage and processing facilities and on employee amenities.
Exploration expenditure will be deductible against assessable receipts of any project established within the exploration permit area.

Where there are two or more projects in a permit area, exploration expenditure deductible in a particular year is to be set off against the project that relates to the production licence which first came into force, then against subsequent projects producing assessable receipts in that year.
Special rules apply where a production licence from one permit area is combined with a production licence from another permit area to form a single project.
I mentioned earlier that the provisions of this Bill take into account the retention lease system introduced in 1985.
Retention leases are of considerable benefit to the industry.
They allow title to be held over a promising discovery for a number of years without insisting on any major ongoing exploration or development program in the area.

To prevent potentially significant revenue losses arising from compounding of deductible amounts, exploration expenditure related to a retention lease area will be able to be offset only against projects in that area.
Exploration expenditure in the rest of the permit area will not be deductible against a retention lease project.
That expenditure, if incurred more than five years before the coming into force of a production licence in the retention lease area, will attract compounding at the GDP deflator rate.

General project expenditure comprises expenditure in a production licence area-or combined production licence areas-on the establishment of a project, on recovering and producing a marketable petroleum commodity and on storing that commodity adjacent to the production site.
It includes relevant expenditure on storage and processing facilities and employee amenities.
Closing-down expenditure is made up of expenditure in closing down a petroleum project and specifically includes expenditure on environmental restoration of a project site.

If, at the end of a project's life, there are insufficient assessable receipts for a year against which to offset closing-down expenditure for the year, a tax credit of 40 per cent of the excess expenditure is provided.
Of course, closing-down credits in respect of a project will not be permitted to exceed the petroleum resource rent tax previously paid in respect of the project.
Certain expenditure is specifically excluded from petroleum resource rent tax deductibility.
Examples are interest payments and payments made under a cash bidding system.
As petroleum resource rent tax is to be a deductible expense for income tax purposes, income tax payments are not to be deductible for resource rent tax purposes.
Fringe benefits tax payments are also excluded.
Instalments

The practical operation of the Bill will require the payment of petroleum resource rent tax by instalments in any year in which a person's assessable receipts from a project exceed the deductible expenditure (including any compounded expenditure of previous years).

Three instalments of tax will be payable-determined on the basis of assessable receipts and deductible expenditure in the instalment period and an appropriate proportion of compounded expenditure from previous years.
The liability for tax assessed at the year's end will be reduced by earlier paid instalments for the year.

The Bill also contains the usual machinery provisions of a tax law-dealing with such things as collection and recovery procedures-and provides objection and appeal rights for taxpayers dissatisfied with decisions under the proposed petroleum resource rent tax regime.
Full details of the provisions of the Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated to honourable senators.

Mr President, the Bill in its present form deals with projects that might straddle both a petroleum resource rent tax area and an area under Commonwealth or State jurisdiction and subject to excise and/or royalties.
It does this by apportioning a quantity of petroleum from a project to be subject to petroleum resource rent tax.
This issue raises a number of complex questions-some requiring resolution in Commonwealth-State discussions.

Nevertheless, it is the Government's intention that, for reasons of both administration and industry certainty, the petroleum resource rent tax should apply to the total project where it extends beyond the resource rent tax area.
The Government intends to initiate discussions with the States on the question of treatment of projects which straddle resource rent tax areas and State excise-royalty areas.
Once these questions have been resolved, any necessary amendments will be introduced.
Mr President, on the basis of current world oil prices, it is unlikely that any petroleum resource rent tax revenue will be received before the 1988-89 financial year.

Due to the continuing fluctuations in world oil prices and the uncertainties inherent in predicting success in off-shore petroleum exploration and subsequent production, the amount of revenue likely to be obtained in any year cannot be projected.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to this place.
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX BILL 1987 [No. 2]

Mr President, the assessment Bill I have just introduced provides the legislative framework for determining the off-shore petroleum projects to be subject to petroleum resource rent tax, and the taxable profit of a participant in such a project.
This Bill will formally impose and declare the rate of that tax as 40 per cent.
The explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators also explains the provisions of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to this place.
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX (INTEREST ON UNDERPAYMENTS) BILL 1987 [No. 2]
Mr President, this Bill will formally impose the interest charge payable under section 65 of the proposed Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987, the Bill for which I have just introduced.

Honourable senators will be aware that under section 55 of the Australian Constitution laws imposing taxation may deal only with the imposition of taxation and may not contain any extraneous matters. Because interest payable under section 65 of the assessment Act might technically be regarded as a tax, this Bill is designed to ensure that constitutional requirements are met.
Its provisions are also explained in the memorandum that has been circulated.
I commend the Bill to this place.
PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1987 [No. 2]
The new profit-based taxing regime for off-shore petroleum project is, in respect of those projects, to replace the existing production-based excise and royalty arrangements.
This Bill will amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Act 1967 to effect that replacement.
The Bill will also amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide income tax deductibility for petroleum resource rent tax paid other than by way of instalments.
Conversely, refunds and certain credits of petroleum resource rent tax are to be made subject to income tax.
Decisions under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 will assume greater importance for the Commonwealth with the introduction of petroleum resource rent tax.

That Act is therefore being amended by this Bill to provide for decisions relating to the development of petroleum pools straddling production licence areas, including pools which straddle the outer boundary of the territorial sea, to be taken jointly by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the relevant State or Northern Territory Minister.

The scope of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 is also being extended by the Bill, so that offences against that Act will cover schemes for the fraudulent evasion of petroleum resource rent tax in the same way as they deal with other taxes of the Commonwealth.
Mr President, details of this Bill are also set out in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated.
I commend the Bill to this place.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a new ceiling on the export charge leviable on exports of dried vine fruit; namely currants, sultanas and raisins. At present the operative rate of charge set by regulations and the maximum rate allowed under the Dried Fruits Export Charges Act 1924 are the same.
This Bill seeks to raise the maximum permissible charge under the Act from $15 to $30 per tonne to enable the operative charge rate set by regulations to be increased beyond $15.
Moneys collected under the Act are used to finance the operations of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation which promotes and controls the export of Australian dried vine fruit.

Australian dried vine fruits meet very severe competition on the international market and in the face of this it is imperative that the Corporation be able to continue an effective promotional program in order to maintain market share.

The cost of promoting Australian dried vine fruit on overseas markets has increased significantly as a consequence of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. In addition, the Corporation is now carrying out a wider range of promotional activity. These factors have placed additional funding demands on the Corporation.

The Corporation has therefore sought an increase in the maximum rate of charge to enable an increase in the operative rate to be effected by Regulations. The proposed increase in the maximum rate of charge has the full support of the Australian Dried Fruits Association which is the principal industry organisation.

The amendment proposed in the Bill will have no impact on revenue and expenditure. Any increase in revenue as a result of a subsequent change in the operative charge rate by regulations will be offset by a matching increase in appropriation to fund the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. The Act provides that consultation with the industry must occur before the operative rate can be increased by Regulations.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the replacement of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council by two new national advisory bodies, namely, the National Legal Aid Representative Council and the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee. For convenience I will refer to the bodies as `the Council' and `the Committee'.

The Bill derives from the decision of the Government, which was announced by the Attorney-General on 19 December 1986, to establish a new national structure to administer, co-ordinate and provide advice to the Government on legal aid. The structure comprises three elements, namely, the Council, the Committee and an Office of Legal Aid Administration in the Attorney-General's Department.

The Council and the Committee will advise the Attorney-General and me, as Minister for Justice with responsibility for legal aid, on the full range of legal aid issues including needs, funding, organisation and delivery methods, on a national basis. The Office of Legal Aid Administration, which was established in December 1986, has brought together in a single, externally identifiable unit, all aspects of the management of legal aid policy and funding within the Department thereby substantially improving the managerial control of national legal aid policy and the expenditure of Commonwealth legal aid funds, which comprise by far the greatest single component of the total funds available for legal aid in Australia. In 1986-87 total input to legal aid services from Commonwealth and State sources, other than Aboriginal Legal Services and State funded community legal centres, was $129.6m of which the Commonwealth provided $77.8m-60 per cent.

Before deciding on the new advisory structure the Government considered at length various options and adopted this approach with a view to reconciling the aim of providing a streamlined economical body with the need to provide an appropriate forum for the views of all the various interest groups in legal aid to be heard at the national level.

The history of this legislation began with the establishment in 1978 of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission. The function of the Commission was to provide an overall advisory, co-ordinating and monitoring role in relation to the need for and provision of legal aid in Australia. It had executive as well as advisory responsibilities.

In 1981 the Commission was superseded by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council, as one of a series of measures carried out by the then coalition Government which it said were to reduce administrative costs and increase efficiency. However, the Labor Government allowed the Council to go out of existence in June 1985, when the terms of the then members expired, because the Government considered that the Council had been largely ineffective in its operation. In particular, the Government felt that there was a need to substantially improve the efficiency of the delivery of legal aid services through the State and Territory commissions, and that a reorganisation of the national legal aid structure was required in order to do this.

In seeking to achieve this goal the Commonwealth has taken a fresh approach to the basis on which funds are provided to the States, under Commonwealth-State agreements, in relation to the operation of the legal aid commissions in those States. In April 1987 an agreement with the New South Wales Government regarding the funding of legal aid in that State came into effect. This agreement is seen as a model for renegotiations which have commenced with the four other States where legal aid commissions currently exist and agreements have been in place for some time. Negotiations with the Tasmanian Government will be proposed on the same model. Under the agreement made with New South Wales the Commonwealth and the State provide fixed proportions of the net operating costs of the legal aid commission in that State.

These steps are part of the Commonwealth's overall strategy of continuing its involvement in the funding of legal aid while at the same time ensuring that the States make an equitable contribution towards the total cost of legal aid services and the efficiency, economy and effectiveness of those services.

It is basic to the Government's policy that the provision of legal aid throughout Australia should be such as to ensure that there is uniform access to legal aid, and thus to the judicial system, and that the nature and quality of legal aid services provided does not put assisted persons at a disadvantage on the basis of the particular State or Territory in which they reside. It is envisaged that the two new advisory bodies, which were established in September on an administrative basis, pending the passage of this legislation, will play a key role in analysing the important issues in the legal aid field and, particularly in the present economic climate, will seek ways of providing legal aid more effectively and economically. They can also be expected to examine alternative means of reducing the demand for legal aid by appropriate changes to substantive law and legal procedures.

The Bill provides for the Council to consist of 20 members appointed on the basis of the position they hold, or on the nomination of one of the major legal aid interest groups. Because of its size and nature, the Council will normally meet only once a year.

The membership is as follows: the Chairperson and Director of each State or Territory legal aid commission; the Chairman of the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee; two representatives of the private legal profession; two representatives of the community legal centres; a representative of the Australian Council of Social Service; a representative of the Australian Legal Aid Office; and a representative of the Office of Legal Aid Administration.
Where appropriate, the appointments will be made after consultation with the relevant bodies.

The Bill establishes the Committee as a body comprising 7 members appointed on the basis of their knowledge of or experience in legal assistance or in matters related to the Commonwealth's involvement in legal assistance. Such related matters include financial and management expertise. Although the backgrounds and experience of the individual members should desirably represent a reasonable spread of areas relevant to the provision of legal aid, the committee would not be directly representative of any areas, organisations or groups.

The Committee will be able to raise issues on its own initiative and will also be available to provide advice to the Government on specific areas of legal aid which require attention. The Committee will meet regularly. The number and timing of its meetings will be a matter for it to determine, although it will be required to meet at least twice each year.

The Council and the Committee will, broadly speaking, provide advice and make recommendations on the whole range of legal aid issues, especially the extent of the need for legal assistance and the most effective, economical and desirable ways of satisfying that need. More specifically, these bodies may advise and make recommendations to the Minister on the extent of the need for legal assistance in Australia and cost-effective ways of meeting that need; the effectiveness of delivery methods; reforms to substantive law or other changes which may affect the cost of legal assistance; the level of Commonwealth funds provided for legal assistance; the effectiveness of the arrangements for the application of Commonwealth funds towards the provision of legal assistance; the funding of community legal centres; community legal education; and any other matter relating to the provision of legal assistance.

The differences between the two bodies are essentially those of their nature and orientation: the Council will provide a forum for the major interest groups to express their views once a year whereas the Committee will be primarily a working party which has an essentially practical role. The possibility of efforts of the respective bodies in relation to particular projects being duplicated should be minimised by the presence on the Council of the Chairman of the committee.

The establishment of the Office of Legal Aid Administration within the Attorney-General's Department has created a focus for the management, co-ordination and evaluation of the Commonwealth's legal aid policy and funding. The Office also administers the various schemes under which the Attorney-General may grant financial assistance in respect of legal and quasi judicial proceedings. The Office will provide the necessary secretariat support services, and arrange for and monitor the work of research consultants for the advisory bodies.

The creation of the new advisory bodies as an integral part of the national legal aid structure should contribute substantially to improving and making more cost-effective the use of available resources for the provision of legal aid services.

In conclusion, I take this opportunity to place on record the Attorney-General's and my own appreciation of the work of the successive chairmen of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council-Mr Justice Rae Else-Mitchell and Mr Rowland Ball-those who were members of the Council and those officers of the Attorney-General's Department who worked to the Council, for their commitment and conscientiousness in carrying out the work of the Council during the four years of its existence. I present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

It is not just the Opposition that has been warning the Government that it has to get off this slippery slide and that, unless it makes corrections, the Government's debt will stay there forever. The cost of the present system is out of control.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I would like to refute the claims made by Senator Walters-some of which I think are absolutely outrageous-and, in particular, her claims that Senator Walsh deliberately misled this place. One is the rearrangement of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, increasing its membership by three. The second involves changes in the way payments are made to pharmacists for the processing of prescriptions. The Government is very mindful of the importance of cost containment. I find it quite remarkable that Senator Walters could somehow think that she was criticising the Government when she read out such a comprehensive list of the cost constraints that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has been able to implement within the health portfolio while at the same time maintaining the very comprehensive, adequate and excellent service of health care that is provided in this country. The Government properly has to consider cost constraints, particularly at the time when currently we have lost so much revenue in this country principally through the fall in prices for our primary materials that we sell overseas. —He is hardly likely to have regard to what it will say tomorrow, Senator. Anybody with common sense who read that would understand that the legislation addresses precisely the fear that the honourable senator has raised, but he has raised it in opposition and contrary to what is clearly in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, clause 4 of the Bill requires that any declaration by the Minister removing an item from the list shall be tabled in the Parliament and subject to disallowance. Again, public scrutiny of the Minister's actions is perfectly open and available through the disallowance procedure in the Senate. One objection was that the reasons needed to be put in the disallowance motion. I would have thought that any debate on disallowance would go to those reasons and that it was unnecessary to do anything more than to move for disallowance, if people so feel, about a medication that has been de-listed. This in no way, as has been suggested by the Opposition, gives unfettered power to the Minister to behave irresponsibly; quite the opposite. He shall have regard to what the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee says. Anyhow, under the legislation introduced by the Minister those de-listed pharmaceuticals will be able to be tabled in Parliament and subject to disallowance. There will be very proper, comprehensive public scrutiny of these matters.

It is also suggested that the Minister will rush around de-listing medications, contrary to the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. These are very misleading and unnecessary criticisms. It is entirely proper for the Senate to be concerned that the Minister be required to make decisions and deliberations thoughtfully, taking heed of proper advice from the proper people. I find it interesting that, somehow, this Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee-to go back to Senator Puplick's comment-is okay when it recommends a drug but is somehow not okay when it suggests to the Minister that a drug be de-listed. Senator Puplick cannot have it both ways. If he doubts those words, I recommend that he read the text of his own contribution yesterday. This objection from the Opposition and the proposal from the Australian Democrats by way of amendment is entirely unnecessary because I believe that the Bill has very thoroughly provided for proper scrutiny and proper behaviour in this area.

The other significant changes in this piece of legislation are changes in the way in which pharmacists will be paid for the pharmaceutical benefits that they have provided. That will be done principally in three ways. The pharmacists can submit records to the Department using modern technology, floppy disks or modems, for a more rapid assessment of the pharmaceuticals that they have dispensed. They will then receive their due repayment in a faster turnaround time. As well, to encourage participation in that scheme they will be afforded 2.5c per pharmaceutical benefit. It is my understanding that about 37 per cent of pharmacists are now preferring to take up that option. That figure has increased from 11 per cent.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3 p.m., pursuant to order the Senate will now proceed to questions without notice.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Walters-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation following Senator Crowley's speech. I claim to have been misrepresented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that that be done after Senator Crowley finishes her speech.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance both as Acting Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware that the Steel Industry Authority reports that time lost through industrial disputes in the steel industry more than doubled last financial year; and at Port Kembla the situation in the June quarter was much worse than during the three years before the start of the Government's steel industry plan; and that there has been what the Authority describes as `an alarming downturn in productivity'? Is the Minister further aware that during the June quarter productivity per employee dropped below the level set as an initial target almost four years ago as part of the unions' commitment to the plan? What action will the Government take to ensure that the union movement fulfils its obligations under the steel industry plan? Also, how, in these circumstances, can the Government justify abandoning its promise to introduce a more effective system of enforcing decisions of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis said, among other things, that in the June quarter of this year the industrial record in the steel industry was worse than it was before the steel plan commenced. He asked whether I knew that. I did not know that that was the case. But, although I am not sure of the facts, that does not necessarily mean that that was worse than it was in 1982 in the pre-accord days. I was aware of most of the other facts that Senator Lewis mentioned; that is, that the industrial record during the June quarter was certainly not good and that there had been a substantial decline in productivity compared with the, by Australian standards, high levels which had been achieved in 1985.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked what the Government can do about it. Firstly, I agree that it is deplorable that, after the company has met its obligations in terms of investment-indeed, in terms of quantity it has more than met its obligations under the plan-and the Government has met the obligations it accepted in 1983, the work force is actually letting the agreement down. I think that is very bad. If the people concerned are interested in keeping their jobs, they had better lift their game in comparison with what it was in the June quarter.

Other than that, what governments can do is certainly not helped by examples set by groups in the community such as the doctors union in the Australian Capital Territory which is going for a 69 per cent pay increase and which, with the active support of a number of members of the Liberal Party of Australia, has been running an industrial campaign for six months based on work bans. It is difficult in circumstances where the doctors union is going for a 69 per cent pay increase and running an industrial campaign based on work bans in support of it, for moral suasion to be particularly effective, particularly when it is directed against people who earn a great deal less than do the members of the doctors union in the Australian Capital Territory. Equally relevant in that context, of course, is the unequivocal statement this morning by an official of the New South Wales doctors union that the doctors union would support any general practitioner in New South Wales who charged $30 for a standard consultation. That, of course, is an unashamed expression of support for the unbridled greed of certain right wing ideologues who unfortunately presently dominate the doctors union in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is to the Minister representing the Treasurer, relates to comments made by Senator Stone yesterday afternoon regarding the workings of the foreign exchange market. Does the Minister recall that Senator Stone asserted that recent developments on the foreign exchange market provide clear evidence that a large capital outflow from Australia has been taking place and that a substantial shift in economic policies is therefore called for? Can the Minister indicate whether that assertion is valid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the debate on a matter of urgency, Senator Stone said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . if the Reserve Bank of Australia was buying, as it certainly was, massive amounts of Australian dollars-amounts of $2 billion were even mentioned-somebody must have been selling them . . . The only people who could have been were those withdrawing capital from Australia.

The first part of that quotation is self-evidently true. If the Reserve Bank of Australia was buying dollars, somebody had to be selling them. However, the second assertion-that is, the only people who could have been selling were those withdrawing capital from Australia-is both theoretically flawed and, I believe, empirically erroneous. If it is not entirely true it is almost entirely true that in the days of rigid currency controls and international currency transactions heavy buying by the Reserve Bank would have signalled, if not absolutely close to absolutely, that capital was being withdrawn from Australia. That was the system with which Senator Stone was familiar and which, as Secretary to the Treasury, he was very eager to preserve, in spite of the free market rhetoric which he used to mouth at that time about all the regulations that he as the Treasury Secretary was not involved in enforcing.

However, we now live in a different world. Under the present system, exporters can choose when they want to convert their foreign exchange into Australian dollars. An exporter who believed that the Australian dollar exchange rate was going to rise, as probably most exporters did a couple of weeks ago, would have an incentive to convert as quickly as possible in order to get a more favourable conversion rate. Likewise, importers can now choose the date on which they purchase the foreign exchange which they need to pay for their imports. But if the mood of the foreign exchange markets switches from expecting the Australian dollar to rise to regarding it as having been too high, and therefore falling or likely to fall further, there can be expected to be a quite dramatic surge of foreign exchange buying which is completely unrelated to any withdrawal of capital from Australia in the sense of hot money leaving the country, or equity in Australian companies owned by foreigners being sold.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leads and lags constitute hot money, Minister.

—Senator Stone said that the only people who could have been selling dollars to the Reserve Bank were those withdrawing capital from Australia. I repeat: While that may have been true in the highly regulated interventionist empire in Treasury over which Senator Stone presided for a number of years, we now live in a different world. In the empire that Senator Stone knew, exporters and importers were obliged, by Reserve Bank direction, to do their currency conversions virtually as soon as possible. That no longer applies and exporters and importers can choose the time at which they do the conversions and, therefore, affect the volume of trading in Australian dollars. If both the exporters and the importers have similar expectations, as they probably did, there is a double whammy effect.

ANSWER.PARA: I can see that Senator Stone is caught in a time warp on this issue. He is caught in time warps on other issues as well, usually far more antediluvian than the world of fixed exchange rates. If he wants to study the subject a bit further, I could make two suggestions: The first is that he seek some advice from somebody presently in the Parliament on his side of politics who has had very recent experience in the area of merchant banking and that, of course, is Professor Hewson. If he finds it too humiliating to take a tutorial from a mere meretricious player who, at one stage, flitted across the stage, I could possibly arrange a tutorial from either Treasury officials who are familiar with the new system or possibly the Reserve Bank of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of recent claims of fraudulent practice by persons advertising as immigration agents, including a former Queensland State Labor member of parliament? Can the Minister confirm the report in today's Press that private agencies will be used to promote, screen and select migrants under the $1.2 billion a year business migration program? How does the Government propose to guarantee the integrity of such a system to prevent the introduction of possible corruption into Australia's migration procedures and to protect the reputation of legitimate business migrants and legitimate business migration consultants? Will the only Government control be to authorise character checks and to stamp visas? If so, will the right to residency in Australia now be up for sale?

—I thank Senator Short for his question. I am aware of the news items that he raises. Of course there is concern about some of these allegations. I am not in a position today to answer specifically the details of his question because the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, has foreshadowed a proposal to co-operate with the private sector and to carry out business migration processing by accrediting a number of private and public agencies. Senator Short will then be fully aware of the Government's proposals.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Did I understand the Minister to say that Minister Young has agreed to co-operate with the private sector in this regard? If that is the case, does that mean that the Minister's announcement, whatever it may be, on Thursday will constitute only the details of the question I have asked her?

—Does the Acting Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce agree with Dr G. Hellestrand that 96 per cent of the Australian computer market and 90 per cent of the local telecommunications industry are owned by foreign transnational corporations or companies based abroad, as reported in the Australian Financial Review of 26 October? Does Australia borrow over $7 billion a year from international money markets to pay for these high-tech imports? What steps has the Government taken to encourage the growth and expansion of an indigenous information technology industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information which says that some of the figures quoted by Dr Hellestrand are substantially correct. Foreign owned firms supply over 90 per cent of the Australian market for computer and communications equipment. However, not all that equipment is imported. Foreign owned firms are also major producers of information technology equipment in services in Australia. It is not correct that Australia borrows $7 billion a year to pay for imported information technology products. But we run a trade deficit of around $4 billion, which is the outcome of a high level of imported hardware and the rather low level of exports, around $140m.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government recently has taken effective steps to encourage the growth of the Australian information technology industry by announcing, in early September, a far-reaching information industry strategy which is largely aimed at rapidly boosting exports of these products to at least $1.5 billion, or around 10 times the current level, by the mid-1990s. An important element of that growth will come from the export of local products by large international companies, facilitated by the corporate citizenship scheme which has received wide media coverage. To date, six of those companies have undertaken to lift exports by $300m within seven years, and local companies will be the major beneficiaries of that expansion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the Australia-Japan Foundation, a body which is vested under the control of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade by the Australia-Japan Foundation Act 1976. Is it a fact that the Minister sought advice from the legal division of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on the best way to abolish or dissolve the Australia-Japan Foundation? Is it not a fact that the Minister's office was furnished with that advice in a minute from the Department, dated 11 September 1987? What was the advice? When will the Government finalise its decision on the future of the Foundation and make public that decision? Can the Minister explain why, at a time when Australia's chronic trade deficits continue to fuel Australia's foreign debt, the Government should consider abolishing one of the very few organisations designed to foster cultural and commercial contacts with Australia's largest trading partner?
—I have no brief on that matter. I will refer it to the Minister and seek an early reply.

—I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General whether his attention has been drawn to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 November 1987 which draws attention to evidence given to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct that the Queensland Police Commissioner, Sir Terence Lewis, may have taped all telephone calls to his office. Would such activities contravene the provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act?

—My attention has been drawn to an article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald where it is reported that a Mr Noel Dwyer, one-time head of the licensing branch in Queensland-I think between 21 January 1980 and 17 September 1982-in evidence before the inquiry said that he assumed that it was the practice in the Police Commissioner's office to tape all calls, as he said, `mainly for accuracy'. I stress that Mr Dwyer is making an assumption and the weight of that evidence, of course, is still to be assessed. It may be of interest to honourable senators to know that under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, it is unlawful for any person to listen to or record a communication passing over the telecommunications system without the knowledge of the person making the communication. If a communication is listened to or recorded after it emerges from the telecommunications system, for example, by means of a tape recorder not attached to the telephone which picks up sounds that have left the handset, an interception for the purposes of the Act probably does not occur. I do not want to give a legal opinion on this set of facts. If the report is accurate, it is possible that the Queensland Police Commissioner has engaged in activity constituting interception for the purposes of the Act. The Australian Federal Police, if more information comes to light, may be in a position to investigate any contravention of the Act.

—I ask the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, since he has had 24 hours notice of this question and in the light of his assertion that figures relevant to overseas trips and expenses are well known, whether he can now provide for the Senate the cost of the trip currently being undertaken by his senior Minister, Mr John Brown? Will it be greater or less in cost than the average $1,658 per day incurred by Mr Brown's trips between March 1983 and June 1986? Will it involve expenditure on meals and accommodation greater or less than the $592 per day spent by Mr Brown in 1984? During his 15 days will car hire cost be more or less than the $10,476 spent for 18 days in Los Angeles in 1985? Will the cost of this trip exceed the all time record set by Mr Brown in 1983 when his trip cost $69,531? Finally, while the Minister is in Egypt will he be apologising to the Egyptian authorities for the failure of his Government or its agents to respond to the offer made by the Egyptian Government to send the fabulous Rameses II exhibition to Australia during our bicentennial celebrations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked a number of questions. I did not get them all down, but I think I got the drift. I would like to take the Senate through Mr Brown's trip so that we all know what Mr Brown is doing. There seems to be some interest in the subject. So, sit back, take it easy, here I go.

ANSWER.PARA: During the Prime Minister's visit to Egypt earlier this year, the Egyptian Prime Minister and the Minister for Tourism and Aviation sought Australian assistance in encouraging tourism in Egypt. Egypt, as I am sure all honourable senators will be aware, faces enormous economic problems, partly due to the collapse of tourism in the past few years. There are a number of factors inhibiting tourism to Egypt and the Egyptians are conscious that their international marketing needs to be improved. Egypt is a vital market for Australian wheat, again as I am sure all honourable senators will be aware. Therefore, it is decidedly in Australia's best interests to respond in a positive way to Egypt's request.

Since the Minister's arrival in Cairo there have been lengthy discussions with senior officers of the Tourism Ministry and with the Minister for Tourism, Dr Sultan. On behalf of the Prime Minister, Mr Brown formally invited Dr Sultan to visit Australia to discuss tourism developments. Mr Brown also advised Dr Sultan that he would take up with Qantas Airways Ltd the possibility of that airline using Cairo as well as Bahrain as a stopover on the way to London. Early tomorrow Australian time Mr Brown will meet the Egyptian Prime Minister, Dr Sidqi, to discuss both trade and tourism issues and the possibility of signing a memorandum of understanding between the two countries. I think the important thing to note is that this is an official visit paid for by the Egyptian Government and formally requested by it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apologise!

—We have not finished yet. I turn to the Minister's visit to Japan, which also seems to have aroused some interest. Mr Brown is leading a tourism investment mission and on that mission there are 19 senior industry executives led by the Chairman of Tourism Australia, Mr John Haddad, who will assist Mr Brown as deputy leader of that mission. I shall table for honourable senators if they are interested a list of those senior executives.
—Read the list.

—Do not tempt me. I shall table the list of the senior executives who are accompanying Mr Brown. The mission members are paying all their own costs. But more than that, it should be noted that all members of the mission put in $300,000 to fund not only meals, cars or whatever, but the seminars and the documentation that will be handed out to prospective Japanese investors. Such a demonstration of confidence not only in the Australian Government but in the Minister responsible, Mr Brown, is something of which we should all take considerable note. Unlike those opposite who carp and criticise, the industry is interested in getting on with the job, and that is what Mr Brown is all about.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Brown is having two whole days in London during which time he will hold a series of meetings with regional directors of Tourism Australia. I would have thought that when one looks at what Mr Brown is doing over this 15-day period, one could only regard this trip as arduous. It is being undertaken, as usual, with the interests of Australia in mind. We should all express our gratitude to Mr Brown, not only for undertaking this arduous exercise but also for all the exercises that he has undertaken in the last few years. At the end of that period we can now look at an industry that is providing 6 per cent of our employment and 6 per cent of gross domestic product-an industry that was totally ignored by Fraser-Howard governments, banished to the boondocks as a mere branch of another department, but uplifted and put in its proper place under the leadership of John Brown.

Yesterday I mentioned the 100 per cent increase in visitor arrivals that has been achieved while Mr Brown has been the Minister. On the question of whether Mr Brown's costs will exceed $69,531, it should be noted that the costs are not all in yet. I imagine that it would take some little time before they are. The responsibility for releasing those figures in due course rests with my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray. I am sure that he will be only too pleased to do so when those figures are available. When they are available, all they will demonstrate, once again, is the superb leadership which Mr Brown has shown in an important industry, made much more important by his interest and his actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Since the Minister asserts that he cannot say what the cost is but that it is likely to be zero, or at least that Mr Brown's expenses will have to be borne by one of the poorest countries in the world, will the Minister now respond to the last part of the question that I asked, which relates to tourism with Egypt? Since the Minister has asserted that the purpose of this trip is to promote tourism from and in Egypt, can he now say why his Government was derelict in not properly responding to the offer made by the Egyptian Government to send one of the most important archaeological exhibitions in the world to Australia to promote tourism? Is it true that the Egyptian Government, having made this very important and generous offer and having received no adequate response whatsoever from the Australian Government, has been saddled instead with a visit by Mr Brown?
—I repeat my answer for Senator Puplick, who obviously sometimes has difficulty in hearing. I will say it as slowly as I possibly can.
—In Egyptian.
—No, I will not speak in Egyptian. This visit was formally requested by the Egyptian Government.
—That was not the question.

—I am sorry, that was part of the question. There was a long preamble, Senator Baume, as there always is with Senator Puplick. This was a visit formally requested by the Egyptian Government to which Mr Brown, on behalf of the Australian Government, has very properly responded. Insofar as the purpose of the visit is concerned, I have made it clear that the Egyptian Government is particularly interested in securing the knowledge and the expertise of Mr Brown relating to the problems that it has had with the international marketing of Egypt as a tourist venue. That is what I said earlier, but apparently Senator Puplick did not hear me. As far as the exhibition is concerned, all I can say is that I will refer that question to my colleague who is in charge of the Bicentenary and seek an answer for Senator Puplick at some stage in the future.

—Does the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and for the Bicentenary agree with recent calls for major changes to school curricula to address the low participation of girls studying maths and science? Does the Government plan to introduce any initiatives to increase the retention rate of girls in the study of maths, science and technology subjects? Can the Minister tell the Senate whether such initiatives will support and expand the success of the Government's affirmative action strategies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government has been working for some years on strategies to improve the participation of girls in science, maths and technological subjects. As a part of the major effort we have made in that direction we have concluded recently with the States and with the major non-government school systems a national strategy for the education of girls which will involve all major school systems taking steps to improve participation by girls across the curriculum but particularly in the science and maths areas and their reporting annually on the results that they have achieved by those methods. The fact that the States and the major non-government school systems are prepared to be involved in a systematic evaluation and measuring, with publication of the results, is a real breakthrough because it is not always easy to achieve that degree of concentration and that systematic examination of what is actually happening in our schools.

ANSWER.PARA: As well as that we have undertaken a number of special initiatives. The most recent is a $1m project which is designed to increase the retention of girls in those subjects. Over two years this project will be directed towards refining and publishing existing curricula material, assisting in the development of materials already in production and developing new materials and strategies. The benefits of this concerted effort for girls in science subjects will be far-reaching. As Senator Crowley's question suggested, it is crucial that we get a better result in girls' participation in science and maths if the new opportunities in employment and training that are being opened up as a result of the affirmative action legislation and other employment policies of our Government are to make a difference.

The legislative and policy changes have been put in place. Opportunities now exist for girls and women in a variety of careers which never existed before. So that they will be able to take advantage of those legislative and policy improvements it is necessary that there be a dramatic change in the curriculum choices of girls. The involvement of girls in the science and maths project, the $1m a year project I have referred to, is an example of the kinds of steps the Commonwealth is taking.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Last Thursday, during debate on the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill in the Senate, Senator Walsh said:

QUESTION.PARA: Total spending on health as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) in Australia has declined in recent years, albeit marginally. It currently stands at around 7 1/2 per cent of GDP.
Can the Minister say where he got that figure? Was it a current figure for 1987-88?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that even Senator Walters would be able to work out that one cannot give outcome figures for 1987-88. Not only would one have to be clairvoyant; one would have to be infallibly clairvoyant to know what the outcome figures for 1987-88 will be. I am not sure what financial year it was. I think it was 1986-87, or it may have been 1985-86. Over a two-year period total health spending as a proportion of GDP fell from 7.52 per cent to 7.48 per cent-a decline, albeit, as I said, marginal. That was the outcome of a study done by a joint interdepartmental committee of the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Finance and the Department of Health. The Health Insurance Commission may also have been represented. I am not certain.
—Was that the one headed by Dr Deeble?

—I cannot say. I presume that as Senator Stone chose to make that interjection he assumes that Dr Deeble has the same sort of blind ideological prejudice that Senator Stone so frequently displays, including not updating his knowledge of the foreign exchange markets since he presided over the very tight, highly regulated little empire back in the days before the market was deregulated.

ANSWER.PARA: It is unpleasant, I know, for people like Senator Walters and Senator Stone when the facts collide with ideological prejudice. The facts that I have just given are an example of that. Since the Medicare policy settled down, total health spending as a proportion of GDP has actually fallen. The same study from that joint committee also showed that total health spending in the United States equals 11 per cent of gross domestic product. If total health spending in Australia were to rise to that level, it would require about an extra $10 billion-for a health service delivery outcome which most people in the United States would regard as inferior, and certainly only the blindest, most obsessive bigots would regard as superior. The very bad, very cost inefficient outcome in the United States is a function of two things: the Federal Government picks up the entire bill for the treatment of the elderly and allows private insurance for others. In other words, that would be the outcome of the very policy which the ideological bigots of the Liberal and National parties would inflict on Australia if they were given the opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. As the Minister is unable to remember the year for the figures which he cited, although he said they were current figures, could he please give me, before the end of Question Time, the year for which he was citing figures. He said he did not know whether they were for 1986-87 or 1985-86. The Australian Bureau of Statistics tells me that only the figures for 1984-85 show the figures cited by the Minister.
—If they can be obtained in time, I will give the years. But I repeat that I cannot give the figures for 1987-88, and nor can anybody else.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware of a report in the Australian Financial Review of 19 October suggesting that Australia is denying refugee status to Fijians? In the light of recent developments in Fiji, where opponents of the military regime have been subjected to psychological and physical torture, is this refusal of the Government to grant refugee status to victims consistent with our recognition of the importance of defending human rights? Has the Australian Government received requests for the refugee status from Fijians who have been mistreated in Fiji?

—I advise Senator Wood that, yes, the Australian Financial Review article of 19 October did state that Indian Fijians would be treated like any other refugee or migrant applicants. Secondly, allegations that opponents of the military regime have been subjected to psychological and physical torture are under active investigation. Since the first coup in Fiji earlier this year, the Department has received 14 formal applications for refugee status from Fijians. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I refer the Minister to his recent announcement that Australia would have its own Antarctic vessel by 1990. Is it not true that the Government took 2 1/2 years to reach this decision? Is it a fact that it had been expected that the 26-year-old Nella Dan would conduct its last expedition in the summer of 1987-88? As evidence of this, I quote an answer given to Estimates Committee A on 18 May this year when it was stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It is hoped that the replacement for the Nella Dan will be available for service by the 1988-89 season.

Is it a fact that the delay in the Government's decision means that the Nella Dan will now have to be recommissioned for the 1988-89 expedition at a likely cost of more than $2m? Is it a fact that the Director of the Antarctic Division recently described the Nella Dan as `dangerous' and explained that last season she only narrowly escaped being `run over as if it were a toy' by an iceberg, a commodity in some abundance in the Antarctic area? What excuse does the Minister have for unnecessarily placing at risk the lives of Australian scientific expeditioners to the Antarctic for the next two years, particularly in the 1988-89 season?

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Archer obviously needs to know is that the Nella Dan was recently refurbished at a cost of $1 1/2m to enable it to continue. We are informed that the owners are confident that it can continue to perform its duties until a replacement vessel is ready. Were that not the case, given the safety aspects of the issue, the Government obviously would not be in a position to continue to run it. However, because of the information we have received, we are confident that the need for a vessel can be held off until the 1989-90 season. To that end I will be making a Cabinet submission within the next month, and I hope we can announce very shortly thereafter the results of it. The Government will have before it a number of options. It is probably not productive to canvass all of them now, given that some of my colleagues may have different views, but I will inform Senator Archer at the earliest possible moment of our decision.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister received proposals for adjustment to fiscal policy settings in the wake of recent events on world stock markets? What is the nature of these proposals, and will the Government be implementing them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been calls from various Liberal Party and other party spokesmen, such as Mr Howard, Mr Peacock and Mr Elliott, as well as Senator Stone, for a mini-Budget to be brought in before the evidence upon which any mini-Budget or economic policy adjustment could rationally be based is available. That, of course, is consistent with the propensity of at least some of the people I have mentioned to determine policy, not after examination of the facts and the evidence, but in accordance with ideological preconceived conclusions. They may differ to some extent in that propensity, but what they all have in common is an inability, or a refusal, to address the details of the expenditure cuts that they are continually calling for. The Liberal Party still has a $2.5 billion plus gap in expenditure cuts arising from the last election campaign, to which it ought to add any other expenditure cuts which it proposes to make or believes should be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 3 November, from Senator Lewis:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to bring to an end union sabotage of the steel industry plan.'
Senator for the State of Victoria
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to bring to an end union sabotage of the steel industry plan.

Last week the Steel Industry Authority produced its quarterly report for the quarter ending June 1987, and yesterday the Authority's annual report for 1986-87 was tabled in the Senate. The figures revealed in both reports indicate an appalling state of industrial disputation in the steel industry during the first half of this year in particular. The position last year was not very good when the annual report was tabled, because in October of that year Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, commented on the rising level of industrial disputation which was revealed in the report and urged the parties to bring about a reversal of this trend. Quite correctly, he pointed out that industrial relations problems reduce Australia's competitiveness and undermine our credibility in world markets.

Clearly, Senator Button's appeal has failed as the number of man hours lost has more than doubled this year. The figures reveal quite alarming statistics, as I have mentioned, and I shall quote some of those figures. I would point out that productivity has declined from an average of 286 tonnes per employee in 1985-86 to 267 tonnes per employee for the whole of the year 1986-87. In the three months to June 1987 the industry's productivity declined further to an average of 245 tonnes per employee per year, which is less than the original estimate, when the plan was introduced four years ago, of 250 tonnes per employee per annum-and that was estimated to be the absolute minimum that the steel industry should be producing in Australia.

The figures show massive strikes being carried out, in particular at the Port Kembla works. For the first six months of this year at Port Kembla there were 321,088 man hours lost, a 779 per cent increase over the same period in the previous year. That figure is more than the total man hours lost at Port Kembla for the period January 1984 to December 1986-that is, the rest of the life of the steel plan. Overall, in 1986-87, 426,649 man hours were lost through industrial disputes compared with 211,294 man hours in 1985-86, an increase of over 100 per cent. I do not want to bore the Senate with figures, but these figures simply have to be stated in order to indicate the nature of the problem. They involve massive disputation, particularly at Port Kembla. I quote from the Authority's annual report:

Each of the three major steelmaking centres recorded falling productivity levels in the six months ending June 1987 with total productivity falling by 11.3 per cent in that period. . . . In April 1987, the Port Kembla steelworks produced 187 tonnes per employee per annum, the worst production figures for any of the three main steelworks since before the start of the plan.

Having established the position, I move on to the crucial part of this motion, and that is what the Government will do about it. The steel plan does not give, within itself, any power to anyone to take any action other than through the normal procedures, so the Government has again urged the steel unions and management to work towards common objectives. I suggest that such gentle urgings are plainly not working. The shortsighted attitudes of the unions should not be allowed to torpedo any chance that Australia may have left to establish and maintain a permanently viable steel industry. After all, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) has invested more than $1.2 billion in the steel plan and has put Australia in a position where our productivity could be such that we could have a very worthwhile steel industry. But, as I said, it is being torpedoed by the actions of the unions involved in this industry up until now. I might add that there is another problem. There is a bit of a power play going on between the local secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia at Port Kembla and the federal secretary, also at Port Kembla. The local secretary is apparently endeavouring to prove that the federal secretary has no authority in Port Kembla.

My criticism is of the Government's failure to take action in industrial relations generally. I point out that on 14 May this year, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, introduced the Industrial Relations Bill 1987. He said:

An essential element of any industrial relations system . . . is that there should be effective means of ensuring adherence to the principles on which the system is founded and compliance with the decisions of its institutions.
He added:

The principal initiative is that the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

In May of this year the Government Minister admitted that the present legislation was moribund and in disrepute. We were promised a new clause to deal with industrial relations disputation. That was on 14 May. Only 12 days later-on 26 May-Minister Willis announced that he would defer that proposal. It would not be debated; merely left to lie on the table. At that stage we wondered why he was saying that, but we found out the very next day because on 27 May the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced an election for 11 July. On 29 June the Prime Minister, in an interview with the Melbourne Age, said to the public:
I say unequivocally that we will be leaving the enforcement and sanction provisions as they are.

That is our major criticism of the Government-that the Minister, Mr Willis, acknowledged that the sanction and enforcement provisions were moribund and should be replaced, yet when the Prime Minister decided to call an election all of those proceedings were put into the waste paper basket because the Government did not want to offend the trade union movement in any way. We are in a situation where this sort of disputation can go on, as it has at Port Kembla, without the benefit of any modern legislation to deal with it. That is the kernel of the resolution which I am asking the Senate to carry as a matter of urgency.

As I mentioned before, BHP, by investing $1.2 billion in plant and equipment and by making no involuntary retrenchments, has fulfilled its part of the plan. But the unions are not carrying out their part of the plan. Unfortunately, there are no sanction provisions in the steel plan. When this steel plan commenced in 1984 these unions were quieter and there appeared to be a general spirit of co-operation. Productivity increased and there appeared to be a close working relationship developing between the union movement and the employers. But it then became clear that a number of union officials and members had no intention of mending their ways. The disastrous political strike over the New South Wales workers compensation issue became the final straw. In March 1987, two orders were issued by the Industrial Commission in New South Wales on two issues at Port Kembla. In both cases the local branch of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia chose to ignore the Commission's orders. One of these disputes resulted in the shut down for six days of BHP's most critical production unit-the hot strip mill-which almost resulted in a major stand-down in the automotive industry through feed shortages.

Problems run deeper as unions appear to be prepared to condone the disregard of undertakings they have given to support productivity improvements which are not associated with capital expenditure-mostly in the form of work practice changes. In May 1987 Uncle Ben's of Australia, the largest user of food tin-plate, was forced to begin standing down its 500 workers at Wodonga because Port Kembla was unable to supply the tin-plate as a result of rolling strikes. These rolling strikes by the South Coast trade union movement, in attempting to force changes in the New South Wales State Government's workers compensation plan, cost BHP a very substantial sum-I believe it was in excess of $25m. I would like to quote what the President of the Industrial Commission of New South Wales, Mr Justice Fisher, told the South Coast unionists at a full bench hearing. He said:
It seems you are standing fairly much alone.

He went on to describe the behaviour of the Federated Ironworkers Association and the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union as `industrial anarchy'. He severely criticised them for using BHP as a battering ram to force the New South Wales Government to amend its workers compensation legislation. This campaign was quite contrary to the principles of the steel plan. In effect, the unionists at Port Kembla were endeavouring to force the New South Wales Government to change its workers compensation legislation by having a strike against BHP. That in no way was part of what was originally described in the steel plan as `the unions' commitments'. The Steel Industry Authority report says:

The unions agreed that wage costs would be contained within prevailing community standards, consistent with the Prices and Incomes Accord; as an initial target, to re-establish a productivity level of 250 tonnes per employee per annum with future increases to be above the trend rate in national productivity; and to adhere strictly to established grievance settlement procedures.

In what way was this dispute-a dispute between the trade union movement and the New South Wales Government-in any way complying with that undertaking? It was not until 22 September this year that the unions finally agreed to a solution. They agreed to distribute a leaflet to their members, including the redrafted policy on the dispute settlement procedure, four years after the plan had been agreed to. The Port Kembla steel unions, having done irreparable damage to the steel plan, are now to meet a Federal Labor Caucus committee in Canberra tomorrow to outline their case against the BHP Steel International decision to reduce its Port Kembla work force by attrition and voluntary retirement. Unless in some way or other the Government is able to get the delegates on the shop floor to agree to this sort of plan, the plan is doomed to failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Totally irresponsible.

In the three months ending June 1987 alone-

. . . over 90 per cent of which were at the BHP Port Kembla steelworks.
Why? The third paragraph on page 16 of the report states:

Increased industrial disputes combined with difficult operational and commissioning problems at Port Kembla and Newcastle in the six months to June 1987 resulted in a productivity performance similar to that achieved prior to the plan's inception.
I point out to honourable senators that, despite the problems canvassed in this report, the figures went down only to those applying before the plan's inception. Page 17 of the report states:

While the setback in productivity gains witnessed over the last 12 months reflects, in part, technical difficulties associated with the commissioning of new plant, the Authority . . . is concerned that the opportunity to improve management and work practices in the industry is not being grasped.
It lays the blame fairly and squarely on both management and unions in respect of that criticism. Page 10 of the report states:

The identified decline in production levels corresponds to the period in which BHP experienced considerable difficulties commissioning new plant under its capital investment program. These difficulties were exacerbated by . . . industrial disputes.
They were not caused by them. On page 11, the following comment is made about Port Kembla, which is the problem:

The problem should be solved following implementation of systems currently being commissioned.
Honourable senators should listen to this:

This report correctly lays the major blame for the fall in production right at the feet of the company for failing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Has Senator Baume read it?
—My word I have read it.

—I will fill the quote out for you.
—Senator Baume will have his turn next. I quote again from the report at page 22:

SPEECH.PARA: As previously mentioned, BHP encountered considerable production difficulties during the year, particularly at its Port Kembla plant. SPEECH.PARA: From July 1, the claims of totally incapacitated workers will be limited to the award rate up to a maximum of $500 a week for the first 26 weeks . . .
It goes on to say:

A further article from the same newspaper-I do not have time to quote from all of them; I have about 15 here-states:

Changes to workers' compensation legislation were passed in the NSW Parliament yesterday despite a protest strike by 18,000 workers which has stopped production at BHP's steel plants at Port Kembla . . .
It continues:

Union representatives claim the recent increase in industrial disputes arose because BHP refused to participate in tri-partite talks over the compensation issue as it has done over other issues such as the introduction of new technology.

The need for the Government to bring to an end union sabotage of the steel industry plan.
