Otherwise, they say that workers are sabotaging the industry. That is the point at issue. I am not surprised that industrial action was taken.

It is also very interesting to see what is being done about it. I turn to page 4 of the report. I wish people would read all of it, instead of just the table on page 19. The report, scanty though it is, gives the reason for the dispute, if those opposite would only look for it. It states:

The deterioration in the management-union relationship over recent months, particularly at Port Kembla, is extremely disappointing. The fact that the level of disputation can largely be attributed to issues outside the direct control of the steel industry, namely changes to the NSW workers' compensation legislation, does not reduce the seriousness of recent events.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is not the employers' fault.
—You will get your go.

—In fact I think he is next on the speakers list, so he should just hold still. The fact is that the annual report which Senator Lewis has identified as being the source of this debate condemns him out of his own mouth. The fact is that the report itself ascribes the majority of the production decreases at Port Kembla to the failure in commissioning new plant, not to the industrial disputation which, the report says quite succinctly, `exacerbated' the problem, not caused it. Conveniently, that was totally ignored by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening in respect of the problems which are all acknowledged as serious? I can tell honourable senators what is happening. BHP and the steel unions have reached agreement on written dispute settlement procedures, which in part caused the problems that occurred earlier this year. The unions and BHP have met with the Steel Industry Authority in recent weeks and are pursuing a range of issues in a co-operative manner-that is what we are into on this side of the House-and it has produced the results that we are looking for in the steel industry, including further improvements in work practices, security of employment and improved consultative arrangements.

The fact is-this is a fact; Senator Lewis has also ignored it-that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's productivity is currently approaching the record levels achieved late last year and further improvements are expected as the full benefits of the $1.2 billion investment program begin to be felt. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's raw steel production levels, adversely affected by the hiccup earlier this year, are back to normal levels. I would like to refer to that hiccup. I turn again to the table on page 19, which caused this knee-jerk, shoot-from-the-lip reaction, to look at what sort of hiccup we are talking about, and the great difficulties caused when percentage increases on a low statistical base are used as the focus for an argument. Interestingly enough, this report has used a completely different methodology from that used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures are compiled on the basis of days lost in the industry. For some reason, this report has chosen to use the basis of hours lost in the industry, which, of course, provides a much more dramatic figure than the comparative Australian Bureau of Statistics one. I do not have time to cite the figures but I have looked them up and these figures are far more dramatic. The result is the same but the numbers are bigger.

What is the problem in using percentage increases? I will tell honourable senators what the problem is. In the case of Port Kembla, the decrease in hours lost between June 1986 and December 1986 went from 124,774 to 36,532, a decrease of 70 per cent. That represents 90,000 hours. We can apply that same figure of 90,000 hours to the next quarter, to June 1987. The decrease between June 1986 and December 1986 was 70 per cent. But if we increase by the same 90,000 on that same basis from December 1986 to June 1987, we then get a statistical increase of 240 per cent on the same number of hours. That is always the great danger of using percentage increases on a low base.

I will give a classic example of something that occurred once to me. I was sitting in an aircraft on a flight to somewhere. I picked up an in-flight magazine, which contained an article on the Northern Territory's horticultural enterprise. Referring to a particular crop-I think, from memory, that it was maize-it extolled the virtues of the Northern Territory with the heading, `Northern Territory maize production has doubled in this calendar year'. Being an ex-horticulturist, I though, `My goodness'; I did not even know that we grew the stuff. When I got back to Darwin I found out that the figure was in fact correct. In the year before there had been 100 acres in production and in this particular year there was 200 acres. We had doubled our production. I say to Senator Lewis that that shows the problem of using percentage increases on a low statistical base.

That is probably why the ABS does not use that methodology-thank goodness. So far as the alleged failure of the steel plan is concerned, I have been referring fairly consistently, I think, throughout this debate to the very thing that Senator Lewis tells us was responsible for this motion, the Steel Industry Authority report. Page 11 of that report states in part:

Since the inception of the Steel Industry Plan, and despite continued adverse conditions in the international market, the Australian steel industry has made considerable progress towards the attainment of the Plan's objectives.

So much for this motion. It is in fact a piece of mindless union bashing. I use the term `union bashing' advisedly, because Senator Lewis's appeal to the Senate to support the motion completely failed to mention the fact that this very report pointed out that the industrial action, regrettable though it was, simply exacerbated the major cause of the decrease in production of steel, which was the problems of the company in commissioning new plant. I think Senator Lewis has demonstrated very clearly that this motion is nothing more than union bashing, and it deserves no support whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot support this urgency motion. It does not treat the facts fairly, it is a union bashing motion, it is excessively alarmist and it denigrates the considerable success flowing from the implementation of the steel industry plan, which began in January 1984. I apologise to the Senate in that I am just about to repeat much of what Senator Collins has said, because even though we have been working in different rooms for the last six hours, reading the same documents, we have arrived at precisely the same conclusions, and quite independently.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the gross inadequacies of this motion is that it blatantly ignores the tripartite nature of industrial relations in any nation, that is, a relationship between government, unions and management. Again we find our role in this debate is to ensure realism and fairness. We are happy with this role, particularly in this urgency debate and in any debate. It seems that it is likely to be a role that the Australian Democrats will especially be called upon to play in debates in relation to industrial relations.

It appears that the trigger for this debate is observations made in the annual report of the Steel Industry Authority for 1986-87. They were restated rather starkly by Mark Davis, reporting in this morning's edition of the Australian Financial Review. The Australian Democrats feel that the Davis article and this motion give excessive emphasis to recent problems at Port Kembla, and that the industry's real successes have largely been understated, or completely disregarded, by the supporters of the motion. If we are to be fair in this debate it is important that we acknowledge that bad management practice is as common and as guilty as bad work practice. Likewise, we should acknowledge that the Metal Trades Industry Association has, by and large, established good working relations with metal industry unions; we should acknowledge that the steel industry plan has been more than modestly successful; and we should acknowledge the facts. Unless we are prepared to acknowledge the facts, we will not be doing justice to Australian management, unions or State governments.

Let us look very briefly at the history of the steel industry plan. It was launched in January 1984 for a period of four years and therefore it will be evaluated in December 1988. In essence, it has been working well, considering that it has been working within a fairly difficult economic climate, a climate of shrinking world demand for its product. It has been working in a climate where there has been considerable demand for protectionism, ironically, once again, from the United States of America. It has been working in an economic climate of falling employment in the industry. In fact, within Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries the fall of employment within the industry has been in the order of 43 per cent since 1974, and in the United States it has been in the order of 55 per cent since 1982. I am quoting all of those figures from the controversial report which the Opposition has selectively quoted from as the basis for this motion. The plan has been working in an economic climate where there has generally been excess capacity within the industry, an excess capacity of 100 million tonnes to 120 million tonnes annually. So we believe that the Australian steel industry has performed remarkably well under very difficult circumstances.

It is true, as Senator Collins has said, that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) has been experiencing considerable difficulties in commissioning new plant. But we do not believe that it is fair to sheet those difficulties home to unions. In fact, it is the nature of the advancing technology within this extraordinarily capital intensive industry. The indications are that there is a great deal of potential for the Australian steel industry, and this is acknowledged on page 3 of the report. It is due in part to increased competitiveness flowing from the devaluation of the Australian dollar, but only in part. The industry per se has performed admirably during the three years that have already passed of its four-year pre-evaluation life, and I can cite those achievements. There has been a substantial increase in investment by BHP, in fact an increase in investment of $1.2 billion, which is 50 per cent more than was anticipated. Once again I am referring to page 15 of the report. The reduction in the work force reflects the extraordinarily high level of technological innovation and adaptation which has been undertaken by BHP. This has been reflected in its relatively high profitability during the period. So by any criterion the industry has not performed badly; in fact, it has performed well.

The problem that has been mentioned at Port Kembla is indeed an aberration, partially of the Port Kembla plant, and it reflects the decision by the relevant unions to fight a workers compensation battle with the New South Wales Government concerning its WorkCare program at the Port Kembla plant. So it is an aberration which is specific to a given situation and a given piece of State legislation, in a given location and at a given time. It must be remembered that accident-related legislation is very close to the hearts of those who work in industries such as the steel industry, the mining industry and the building industry. They tend to give it their very close attention. They respond very vigorously and they use their strongest industrial weapons in pursuing their intent. Government's legislative performance in relation to industrial safety and industrial health-I am talking not only about the Federal government but also about State governments-historically has not been good, and that has been true of governments on both sides of politics.

The differences in productivity which are mentioned on pages 16 and 17 of the report do not clearly distinguish between causes, that is, between differences resulting from industrial disputes and differences in productivity resulting from the installation and commissioning of new plants. In that respect, we believe that the figures which were quoted distort the realities. Reductions in productivity reflect not only union problems; management must accept its share of the blame as well. We believe that is one of the gross inadequacies and unfair facets of this motion-it does not accept the fact that management is a partner in this tripartite relationship.

If we are to get to the nub of the question, which really is the level of industrial disputation, we must be very careful with the statistics which we quote. In the May-June period of this year there was this aberration at Port Kembla which, as I said, reflected one particular dispute. I am also teased by the fact that the State Liberal Opposition in New South Wales, and in fact the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales, supported the New South Wales Labor Government in its WorkCare legislation. In doing so they actually precipitated what is the focal dispute at the Port Kembla plant. It is interesting also to note that there is a contradiction between the attitude being displayed here this afternoon by the Opposition in this chamber and that which it displayed in its discussions of the now defunct Industrial Relations Bill when it objected so strongly about access to common law, which is precisely the same right, as Senator Collins has already cited, which was being pursued by the workers at Port Kembla early in the same year.

The Opposition argues frequently that the fall in industrial disputation is a world-wide phenomeno and that the present Federal Labor Government cannot claim any credit for what we consider to be a very creditable record of the last four years. We do not accept the Opposition's claim. We believe that, on a fair examination of the statistics, the Australian level of industrial disputation of the last few years has been very creditable. We would cite the extensive work done by Messrs Begg and Chapman published by the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the Australian National University which appears in the recent edition of the Journal of Industrial Relations. In that work we are warned quite seriously about the way in which we interpret and handle figures concerning industrial disputation.

The real need is to be cautious with motions of this type. I suggest to the chamber that the urgency motions from the Opposition in the last two or three days are superficial. We urge them to practise caution in the use of this medium within this chamber. We suggest that this motion damages, unfairly and unnecessarily, our reputation as a reliable supplier of steel and fails to acknowledge the creditable performance of the Australian steel industry. We urge the Opposition to be more positive, and to acknowledge that co-operation is the vital ingredient in industrial relations. We must all recognise the constitutional and other limits on any government's power to act. We must avoid the Canute syndrome: believing that legislation is the essence of good industrial relations. Of course, that is false. The essence of good industrial relations is co-operation and acknowledgment of achievement. Both State and Federal industrial relations scenes are littered with ineffective legislation which has resulted in failed attempts to provide for industrial peace by fiat.

In conclusion, given the nature of the steel industry and the Government's failure to enact long promised legislation on occupational health and safety, and given the extraordinarily high level of industrial accidents which cost the community $5 billion per year, it is high time that governments, unions and the community at large recognised that the responsibilities for industrial safety in essence lie largely in the hands of governments and management. There is no escaping the fact that the unions, management and governments share responsibilities for our industrial relations. This motion denies that shared responsibility. It misrepresents the facts. It does not assist in building confidence in an Australian industry that has essentially performed well in recent years, despite adverse world markets. For these reasons the Australian Democrats oppose the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard some rubbish from both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats in the past, but today's level of hypocrisy probably reaches an apex. —Read it again; you're wrong.

—It was not party to this particular dispute. I have read it out three times. If the honourable senator cannot understand it after three times, he should go away and try the ABC. On pages 24 and 25 there is clear evidence that the number of disputes is increasing and that dispute settling procedures are not being adhered to. I ask: By whom? The report tells us:

SPEECH.PARA: This was particularly so in the dispute in New South Wales following the introduction by the State Government of new workers' compensation legislation. The Authority believes that the dispute has severely damaged the goodwill and trust which had developed between management and unions since the inception of the Plan in 1984. Moreover the dispute caused hardship and financial losses to BHP, to employees and to the steel producing regions at large.

That issue had nothing to do with management. I remind the Labor Party that that key distinction has been not only glossed over but totally ignored. Yet the words in the report clearly indicate that that is where the crisis has developed. It is a crisis that developed in exclusion, if you like, of the management. It was a dispute basically between the New South Wales Government and the unions. Yet its consequences have been disastrous. It has sabotaged the results of the steel industry plan. Can we look to the evidence of sabotage? Of course we can. We have seen evidence of orders cancelled and widespread problems in this industry. The problems have been so widespread that the Labor Party has avoided making another quotation; that is, that part of the report which says that the future of the industry could be at risk. Page 3 of the report states:

. . . the Australian steel industry has the potential to become the world's lowest cost steel producer and potentially a competitive exporter . . . A failure in the performance of either capital or labour would not only represent a lost opportunity for the Australian steel industry but, given the extremely competitive world steel environment, could jeopardise its existence.

In other words, continual industrial unrest and a failure of capital-I stress `failure of capital'-could jeopardise the existence of the steel industry. Warning was given last year in the annual report of the Steel Industry Authority about the future of the industry as a result of industrial unrest last year. I suppose the Labor Party would say that that was just a one-off, for some special reason. Again, the Labor Party offers another set of excuses. As Senator Collins said, there were problems of capital investment. There is no doubt that there were some warm-up problems. The industry says, quite clearly, that the decline in production or the failure to meet targets this year, was 50 per cent due to delays and difficulties in introducing new capital plant-they were unavoidable-and 50 per cent due to ratbaggery by the union movement, which has unnecessarily undermined and sabotaged the achievement of this plan. That is the point. One cannot possibly find someone to blame if there are technical problems when such an enormous amount of money has been spent. BHP has spent $700m on this. Inevitably there will be some start-up problems. The reality is that they were unavoidable. The important issue, which Senator Collins is too thick to understand, is that it is not only totally unnecessary but also totally damaging and disastrous that there should be this massive level of industrial unrest as the labour movement in Wollongong has failed to meet its obligations under this tripartite arrangement. That is the issue. We are not saying that there are no other reasons for a reduction; we are not saying that there are no other reasons for the failure to meet the targets. We are saying that there were start-up problems and that accounted for about 50 per cent of the decline. We are saying that there is a massively unnecessary level of industrial unrest and that that has jeopardised the future of this industry.

Let us not pretend that this does not exist the way we have heard today. Senator Button has complained about this unnecessary industrial unrest. He does not pretend that it does not exist, the way Senator Collins does, or the way Senator McLean tries to excuse it. Mr West, who is off with the gorillas on his own, swinging through the trees in Wollongong, does not believe that the reduction in employment which is required and which fits into the steel industry plan, as Senator Button said in the Senate Estimates, should take place. Senator Button has criticised the unions. Mr Keating has agreed that there should be a continued reduction in the number of jobs. Also Senator Walsh said today:

. . . it is deplorable that, after the company has met its obligations in terms of investment-indeed, in terms of quantity it has more than met its obligations under the plan-and the Government has met the obligations it accepted in 1983, the work force is letting the agreement down.

Senator Walsh has said that. Yet there has been no acknowledgment of that. According to the Labor Party, it was all because of dreadful management. The Australian Democrats says that it was equally to blame.

The reality is that the case put by the Government and the Democrats is arrant nonsense. There has been a sabotage not simply of the steel industry plan but of $200m of extra investment that the company had planned to spend in Wollongong. That has now been cancelled. That project was for the rebuilding, not just the relining, of No. 4 blast-furnace. It would have meant continued investment in the region, which is now to be brought to a shuddering halt. It is being brought to a shuddering halt not simply because of problems in commissioning new plant but, as was evidenced before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in New South Wales, because of the level of industrial unrest. That evidence was given before the Commission in May this year. At that stage the figure was $165m; it is now about $200m, with ancillary works. The warning that the rebuilding program at Port Kembla steel works could be abandoned because of union activity was given in June and it was ignored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's urgency motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to bring to an end union sabotage of the steel industry plan.

Nothing could more adequately show the difference between this Government and the Opposition than this urgency motion. The Government has introduced one plan after another into Australian industry-plans that stand as monuments to the regrowth and revitalisation of Australian manufacturing industry. The plans, which are well known, concern the heavy engineering, textile, clothing and footwear, and shipbuilding industries. The list goes on. The plans represent, if you like, the mutual tackling of problems by the partners in industry, assisted by the Government, based on co-operation, on changing our industries and on creating a stable climate. Senator McLean, in speaking for the Australian Democrats, acknowledged that his party favours the same approach. It is a common-sense approach. The tackling of management and work practices, investment, infrastructure and regional planning and development are just some of the areas that are looked at in these plans.

Let me now refer to the steel plan. It is true that the Steel Industry Authority has been critical, but I think Senator Collins has dealt adequately with that criticism in a balanced way. The 1986-87 annual report of the Authority analyses and reviews the period ending June of this year. However, we find that since June of this year there has been a significant improvement in the industrial relations situation in the industry. It can be said that the hard won gains of the first three years of the steel plan have been substantially restored.

Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) and the steel unions have reached agreement on written dispute settlement procedures which were a major problem earlier in the year. The unions and BHP have met with steel industry authorities in recent weeks and are pursuing a range of issues in a co-operative manner, including further improvements in work practices, security of employment and improved consultative arrangements. BHP's productivity is currently approaching the record levels achieved late last year and further improvements are expected as the full benefit of the $1.2 billion investment program begins to be felt.

Senator Button has succeeded with his plan, contrary to what Senator Lewis suggested. BHP's raw steel production levels, which were adversely affected earlier this year, are back to normal levels now and that is the important thing. In fact, the September output exceeded the figures for the corresponding month last year. Let us get the matter in balance and away from the hysteria that Senator Lewis and Senator Michael Baume have generated. This is hardly a picture of an industry that has been sabotaged by unions which, I remind the Senate, comprise workers whose future employment opportunities are dependent on the continued viability of the Australian steel industry-an industry that is poised for strong development. The end of the year should reflect the successful achievement of the steel plan's major objectives. That is the background to this matter. The creation of an internationally competitive steel industry is well in place and the advantages to Australia of a powerful steel industry do not need to be emphasised.

Senator McLean said that he did not know whether the trigger for this matter of urgency was an article by Mr Davis in the Australian Financial Review. There is another possibility-BHP Director Elliott, who last Friday became the President of the Liberal Party of Australia. Perhaps this is the reason members of the Opposition rushed into the chamber and moved an urgency motion. Senator Lewis, who is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this place and the Opposition spokesman on industry, has displayed today the Liberal Party's typically one-sided industrial relations policy and industry policy. He is preoccupied with enforcement and sanctions; that is all the Liberal Party understands. The Liberal Party does not seek co-operation with industry but tries to put the boot in. His one-sided and confrontationist style is a classic, but it is even more serious than that.

Everybody should be very offended-two million trade unionists in this country will be offended-by the one-sided language of this urgency motion which refers to union sabotage. I remind honourable senators that the dictionary defines the word `sabotage' as `malicious or wanton destruction'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator Baume says, `Hear, hear!'. `Sabotage' is also defined as the doing of damage to equipment et cetera by dissatisfied workmen or hostile agents. The Liberals agree with that. The violent and emotive language used by members of the Liberal Party cannot be an accident because Senator Lewis, as a barrister, would not use language loosely. So this urgency motion is a conscious effort at provocation by the Liberal Opposition no doubt to appease its new President who is waiting in the wings to see how it performs.

SPEECH.PARA: Faced with this blackguarding of the unions by the Opposition, I have sought some information to find out what the union side is. As a former union official, I realise that in any industrial dispute there are always two sides; it is never a simple position. As the Opposition has spent so much time attacking and it cannot take it--(Quorum formed) Before the quorum was called, I was referring to the fact that there has been distortion by the Opposition in the debate. I want to refer briefly to what the unions say is the problem. Under the steel plan, the unions are committed to achieving initially 250,000 tonnes output per person and then to increasing productivity by more than the national average. The record shows that productivity per worker has generally improved greatly. More recently, however, productivity figures have dropped and we have acknowledged this fact. But the reasons for this drop in productivity are much more complex than the Opposition's simple union bashing exercise would have us believe.

Poor production planning and unrealistic completion dates for commissioning new plant have not only caused disputes but also have led to substantial loses in production. In fact, two-thirds of production loss was due to mismanagement of plant or what the company has termed `operational problems'. This is the view of the trade unions involved. Total costs of these so-called `operational problems' were $56m in Port Kembla alone. This is the evidence that Senator Baume challenged Government senators and Senator McLean to produce. Belatedly in his speech, Senator Baume acknowledged this fact when he said that there was a 50 per cent warm-up problem. It is a damned big warm-up problem for a management that he says does no wrong when $56m was involved in Port Kembla alone. That is not a surprising figure because the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that 40 per cent of industrial disputes in the metal industry are caused by management policies.

The Opposition is congenitally incapable of acknowledging management error in this area. The very point of the industry plan is to try to overcome those problems. Many disputes arise simply because BHP's industrial bureaucracy is slow to respond to these problems. I know that that is likely to be true because when I was a union official BHP traditionally was a company that had a bad industrial relations record. Although I acknowledge that BHP's record has improved in recent times, it has a great deal of ground to make up. Unfortunately, with the advent of Mr Elliott, I am not sure that it will be helped in that process.

Disputes of this nature made up the $45m lost at Port Kembla. While the workers compensation dispute was regrettable-and I do not think that anybody would say other than that-the real reason for the lost production lies squarely with BHP's refusal to change its nineteenth century industrial relations practices. An example is its scare tactic of announcing, during the sensitive second tier wage negotiations, the loss of 4,000 jobs. It is a typical BHP ploy, but something that stirs all the people in such a situation. That is a problem because the many people who have been upset are more likely to be excited and become involved in an industrial dispute.

The bottom line is that BHP still lost more money-the $56m that I have spoken about-through poor management than through all the disputes, amounting to a loss of $48m, at Port Kembla. That is the union's attitude. It is the sort of evidence that Senator Michael Baume challenged us to produce. I will go further with Senator Baume. I will give him a few more things to check up on about BHP management. Unions allege that, at a casual glance, BHP stock levels indicate that large quantities-up to $88m-worth of production-are being stockpiled haphazardly around the Port Kembla plant, because the new technology is not running efficiently enough to finish the work. That is something for Senator Baume to look at because that suggests that management is not being efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it management's fault that you have had these industrial relations problems? The answer is no.

—We have had problems. Senator Baume bubbles away like a can of Fosters. But the reality is that he cannot ignore the fact that many of the problems are management based. I want to go a bit further because the unions have raised one other matter that I think is worth while putting into the equation of this debate. The unions have drawn my attention to the fact that one might speculate on what Mr Elliott is up to. The Australian Financial Review of 2 November states that Mr Elliott said that if BHP shares fell much further, BHP would become a takeover proposition. The question we have to ask-and I hope that everybody will ask it-is: Is Mr Elliott trying to depress the price of BHP shares even further so that he, Holmes a Court, or one of the other people can gobble up the lot?. That is something we have to consider, something that is not in the biased matter of urgency introduced by the Opposition, but it might well be the reason why the Opposition has got so excited today. When its new President told it to jump it jumped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the urgency motion moved by my colleague Senator Lewis:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to bring to an end union sabotage of the steel industry plan.

I would like to point out that every time blame is sheeted home to irresponsible and militant unions for quite irresponsible actions, those opposite-not all and I exclude people like Senator Button and Senator Walsh when I say this-jump around and shout `union bashing'. The union is the sacred cow that is above the law that applies to everyone else. It is worth recounting a little history because in the last two decades we have seen a major restructuring of the steel industry throughout the world. Traditional steel makers and shipbuilders in Britain, the United States and Europe saw the loss of their traditional heavy industries, initially to Japan and then eventually to Taiwan and Korea. A major reason for that was that following the Second World War, Asian countries, particularly Japan, were able to start from scratch and install modern steel mills in locations strategic for the importation of raw materials and the export of finished products. They had the will to do that because they were on a recovery pattern-particularly in Japan. Nothing exercises the mind more than starting from nowhere and trying to build up.

Australia was in a similar position to the traditional areas but did not suffer from the disability of having its mills located in the wrong places. However, it suffered from featherbedding, overmanning, lack of adequate profits and, hence, precluded new capital investment in equipment. Europe-notably France, Italy and Holland-modernised. The recovery of British steel was nothing short of miraculous. It should be pointed out, however, that it was a matter of recover or die. That situation confronted Australia. A concerted effort to modernise the Australian steel industry was undertaken in 1984 with the introduction of Senator Button's industry plan-which was a good plan; there was nothing wrong with it. The purpose of the plan was to give local industry a chance to recover, create a leaner and more profitably operation and, more importantly, survive. A decision had to be made: do we or do we not want a steel industry? Most developed countries would take the view that they need a steel industry, but only if it is viable in the long run.

The plan hinged around three commitments: firstly, the Government bounty; secondly, an investment of $800m by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-I believe that $1.2 billion was spent on re-equipment; and, thirdly, union co-operation in productivity. While the Government certainly has done its bit and BHP has attempted to make the plan work with its $1.2 billion investment in plant and equipment, it is quite apparent that the steel industry unions have not. Senator Collins, in his speech, tended to discount the table on page 19 of the Steel Industry Authority annual report. He said that other factors were involved. Certainly there are other factors, but they are minor. What we must not forget-and we can never forget-is that we had to make a decision: do we want a steel industry or not? Those sorts of decisions were also made in England by companies such as the British Steel Corporation. It was not done, I might say, without some pain. Honourable senators opposite may well think about the example put to us by steel workers from Llanwern in Wales, who would not accept, until orders ran out, that their industry was finished and was going to be shut down. The orders had to run out before something was done. It was like turning on the light switch but the light not coming on. The unfortunate thing is that in an industry matters often have to get to that stage before something happens.

I go back to table 5 in the Steel Industry Authority report. For an industry that was being bailed out by every taxpayer with a bounty, an industry that was relying on over $1 billion-worth of capital investment to modernise it, and that required union co-operation in productivity, the record, I tell Senator Collins, is lousy. It is not a matter of percentages or percentage increases. In the half-year ended June 1984, 62,950 man hours were lost. In December 1984 the figure was 56,062; in June 1985 it was 56,789. The figure came down in December 1985 to 45,253-about which people would say, `That is good. What a great figure that is. In a six month period we had only 45,000 man hours lost'.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are 33,000 workers.

—I tell Senator Collins that that was in an industry that was not going to survive. What is wrong with people in this country when they do not recognise that sort of thing? In December 1986 the figure was 67,255 man hours and, of course, in June 1987 there was the massive figure referred to in this report, in some detail, of 359,394 man hours for the six-month period. The union commitment to the plan was to contain wage costs within prevailing community standards, increase productivity and adhere strictly to the established grievance settlement procedures. The Steel Industry Authority states on page 24 of its annual report:

SPEECH.PARA: There is clear evidence that the number of disputes is increasing and that dispute settling procedures are not being adhered to . . . particularly . . . in New South Wales.

Senator Collins, in his speech, said that the workers had every justification for going on strike because there was a challenge to common law claims under workers compensation. I would point out that, as everyone knows, that amendment was being put through by the New South Wales Government. The strike went on, the competitive structure of the steel industry was damaged, and the reliability of the steelworks was affected. The strike achieved nothing, because the New South Wales Government rammed the legislation through the State Parliament.

I would question whether disputes of this nature are legitimate. There are other ways of protesting, yet Australia has become so used to political protest by strikes, with people taking no account of the effects upon their fellow workers, on jobs and families. Like the road toll, strikes are accepted. If there is a political problem there is political protest by strike. Look at the maritime industry in New South Wales. Disputes occur every month because the maritime unions do not like what happens in South Africa. No account is being taken of Australia's competitiveness, the effects on the balance of payments, families and children.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens to the blacks over there?

—I am pleased to hear Senator Burns interject on that issue. It is not the unions' role to act on foreign affairs. I would have thought that that was the role of this Government and of the Minister concerned. From the information I have in Queensland, I understand that one of the major reasons that we still remain a `branch office' State is the actions of Senator Burns and the people in his union. Over the past six months unions have effectively sabotaged the steel industry plan with a disastrous 10-week strike to which I have just referred. The dispute comprised go-slows, lightning strikes and bans designed to disrupt exports. If that is not sabotage of this country, I will walk to Bourke. This was occurring when we as a nation, month after month, were incurring record balance of payments deficits. Even the Port Kembla maritime unions did their destructive bit by delaying the movement of ships in the port.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth referring to some remarks made by Senator Button on this issue. He went to Wollongong when the Steel Industry Authority was set up and said that Wollongong was a town of doom and gloom, and so it was. The question was whether the industry had a future, and whether there was a formula to do something about the problem. Certainly Senator Button did his best to fix it up. Senator Button said that he was angry, and that what he was angry about was that when he first went to Wollongong there was a sense of doom and gloom, but that when he returned the atmosphere had changed significantly. He then said:

I believe that BHP has worked harder at industrial relations issues than ever before in its history. It's just tragic that this `three steps forward, one step back' breakdown is there again. Really, the unions targeted Wollongong to make their point against the NSW government. That might be all right from their point of view but it's not from mine because the steel industry has so many downstream implications for other industries.
He continued a little later:
Those things have all been set back by the disruption-
he was talking of the possibility of new industries going to Wollongong-

and a lot of it is just political. Now, I don't mind that. But I've always had a detestation of educated-I don't know whether you would call them middle-class or not-but people manipulating for purely personal reasons. I think that's what happened. Some of the things some people said were plain stupid . . . What has been done there really puts at risk the jobs of the steelworkers, their children's future and the town itself.

All that from Senator Button! Senator Button took the view, a view not recognised by the Australian Democrats in their remarks, that where there was blame one should not be fearful of apportioning it: If the blame is at the feet of management, then put it on management. I would not object to that. But when a case such as this puts the whole steel industry at stake, with a plan that was excellent-I have said that a number of times-such a situation cannot be tolerated.

It is not good enough for Ministers just to say that they do not condone or support destructive actions by these lunatics-and they are lunatics because they are putting the industry, probably one of the great industries in Australia, at risk and the people employed in it. It is worth quoting remarks made by Senator Walsh today in answer to a question. He said:

. . . I agree that it is deplorable that, after the company has met its obligations in terms of investment-indeed, in terms of quantity it has more than met its obligations under the plan-and the Government has met the obligations it accepted . . .
It was a tripartite agreement. It involved three parties and two of those parties had met their obligations. Senator Walsh continued:

. . . the work force is actually letting the agreement down. I think that is very bad. If the people concerned are interested in keeping their jobs, they had better lift their game in comparison with what it was in the June quarter.

Those were the words of Senator Walsh. After all, we have a Labor Government which is the political arm of the trade union movement. The people of Australia who are paying the bounty, BHP which has made the investment, and the workers whose jobs are at stake are sick and tired of pious words. Those who are sabotaging a good plan should be accountable for their actions. That a few people can wreak this sort of carnage on a vital Australian industry is criminal, and that the Government can sit back and do nothing is a scandal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate--

—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Childs, in his speech, indirectly, and in the closing minutes of his speech directly, implied quite improper motives to Senator Lewis and the Opposi- tion--
—That is not a point of order.

—I am getting to my point of order-in bringing this matter forward. Accordingly, if that is to be the tone of the debate, I think that Government senators should be here to listen to the debate, and I draw your attention to the state of the--
—There is no point of order.
—I draw the Chair's attention to the state of the House.

—When I saw the terms of the matter of urgency I was amazed that, in view of the importance of the steel industry to Australia, Senator Lewis could draft the motion in such a destructive way. The language used in the motion seeks to give the impression that the steel industry is being destroyed only by the trade union movement. First of all, I reject that completely. The facts and figures in the Steel Industry Authority report show that whatever problem there was earlier this year with industrial disputation at Port Kembla in particular, this was not reflected at Newcastle or Whyalla. This sort of motion shows that in many ways the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have not moved out of the nineteenth century in their attitudes to industrial relations. They still see industrial relation on a master-servant basis, and not on the basis of equality or of people providing labour to help build things in Australia.
—What about equality under the law?

—That is a typical attitude of a National Party senator from Queensland where the Parliament is a mockery of the Westminster system and the electoral system is the worst in the Western world. For Senator Sheil to cite equality under the law to the Australian Labor Party is a joke. He should clean up his own State first and then we will have the basis for an equal debate.

SPEECH.PARA: My next point about the steel industry is the philosophy that this Government has taken in industrial matters. I come from a State where, during the late 1970s, the shipbuilding industry was wiped out in Whyalla by the inaction of the Fraser Government. Fortunately for Australia, and for Whyalla and the steel industry in particular, the Fraser Government was defeated in 1983. Had it not been defeated and had it stayed in office, we would not have a steel industry operating in Whyalla now. That is clear because of the laissez-faire attitude of the Liberal Party, which does not want to be involved in any way in helping industry. I think that the people of Whyalla have realised that on reflection in recent years. The 70 per cent vote for the Australian Labor Party in Federal elections shows that the people understand that their future, their security, involves having a Labor government in Canberra, not a Liberal government, such as the Fraser Government.

Certainly, the steel industry plan has resulted in a loss of jobs in Whyalla. The number of employees in the steel industry has dropped from 6,400 to just over 4,000 at the moment. Certainly we in the Labor Party regret those job losses. But if it were not for the steel industry plan there would not even be 4,000 jobs in Whyalla-there would not be any jobs in Whyalla, Newcastle or Port Kembla in the steel industry at all. The steel industry plan devised by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), saved the steel industry in this country. I heard Senator Parer say that he thought that when the plan was initiated it was a good one. That is an interesting statement when one considers the Press statement, issued on 11 August 1983, from Senator Peter Rae, the then shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce. Of course Senator Rae is no longer a member of the Senate but I understand that he is now a Minister in the Tasmanian Government. His Press release is headed `Government steel industry package a failure'. It goes on:
The Labor Government's Steel Industry package will be not only a disappointment to those involved, but a disappointment to Australia.
Labor promised us `a viable and efficient steel industry', and clearly a long-term, integrated approach was called for.

Senator Rae then listed what he considered to be all the failures of the plan. I will not list them in the short time that I have available, but I will seek leave of the Senate to incorporate this Press statement of 11 August, 1983.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
GOVERNMENT STEEL INDUSTRY PACKAGE
A FAILURE
The Labor Government's Steel Industry package will be not only a disappointment to those involved, but a disappointment to Australia.
Labor promised us ``a viable and efficient steel industry,'' and clearly a long-term, integrated approach was called for.
By comparison, Senator Button's plan:
fails to achieve any solution to the problem of making Australia's steel industry more competitive and more profitable.
fails to ensure that steel consumers in Australia can look to the future with any degree of long-term confidence.
fails to stimulate confidence for long-term investment in steel industry areas.
fails to grasp the nettle on the difficult question of developing country preferences; it has only gone part of the way.
fails to provide for creation of new employment opportunities.
fails to provide stability and certainty in industry policy.
fails to provide a wages structure which will make the steel industry competitive again.

It is consistent with this Government's attitude that ``the down-turn in Australia's manufacturing industry is permanent, irreversible, and structural''. In their stated view, ``it is not temporary, or to be rectified by tariffs, wage freezes, bounties, quotas, or other fiscal measures''.

The Opposition believes that the matter is of such tremendous importance to the long-term future of Australia that we had hoped that, with the combination of the temporary assistance for steel provided by the former Liberal Government, and with adequate time and consultation, the new Government could have come up with a long-term solution.
The Opposition has been careful not to attempt to hassle the Government into fulfilling their rash election promise of a steel industry solution within one hundred days.
Even though they have had more than half as long again, the Minister, Senator Button, has come up with not a solution, but with a steel version of the curate's egg.
What the Government has achieved is some protection of existing employees, but virtually no protection of continued employment opportunities in the steel industry.
The amount of investment is not much more than one quarter of that originally assessed by BHP as being necessary, and will not ensure the total modernisation of the Australian steel industry.

The fact that the package is of five years duration only means that this Government has adopted a stop-gap approach which compares unfavourably with the previous Government's long-term provision for the restoration and re-structuring industries.
There is an absolute need for certainty and stability in policy making. This short-term proposal does not provide that.
The best thing that can be said for it is that the productivity undertakings represent, potentially, a major breakthrough.

Although there is virtually no sanction, there has been a recognition by the trade union movement that, without productivity, protection by way of bounties, quotas, tariffs, and the like, can create a dangerous illusion, leading to the destruction of competitiveness of industry, and thereby its long-term existence, and the jobs which it provides. It is most encouraging to see that the trade union movement is recognising that the quid pro quo for protection must be productivity increases.

Nevertheless, the unions have offered very little indeed. They are still demanding-and the Government has agreed to-4.3 per cent wage increases for the first six months of this year, and full wage indexation beyond.

That will lock Australia's steel industry into its current crisis of unprofitability and lack of competitiveness. While Australia's steel workers are taking a 4.3 per cent wage increase for six months alone, United States steel workers have agreed to a 9 per cent cut in wages. They will forgo cost of living adjustment for a year, and these labour cost-savings are being re-invested in the industry.
That is a genuine contribution by unions to future growth and new jobs.

The Government proposals in relation to anti-dumping procedures and in particular, the speeding up of the process of making information available upon which applications can be based is to be welcomed, and carries on the process commenced under the previous Minister, Hon. Andrew Peacock.

But over all, this vital industry, employing over 25,000 Australians, and so central to the competitiveness of Australian industry as a whole, is being locked into uncompetitiveness. An effective policy should have gone one way or the other-either temporary protection during the crisis, or a policy enabling full re-structuring of the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that that is on the record, I am sure honourable senators will be interested to compare it with Senator Parer's remarks about the steel industry plan being very good. TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 was interrupted, I was referring to the altered provision for payment to pharmacists by the Department of Community Services and Health for the pharmaceuticals that they dispense. I had mentioned the first proposal, that allows for the advantages of modern technology-floppy disks, modems et cetera-used by pharmacists to be provided to the Department so that more rapid repayment and processing of claims can be put in place. As well as the changes contingent on that new technology, there is also an acknowledgment by the Government of its appreciation of people moving to that process of 2 1/2c for each pharmaceutical benefit processed to be paid to pharmacists. I had just come to the point where I wanted to acknowledge the pharmacists who had so readily preferred to go that way. In fact the percentage of pharmacists preferring to exercise that option has increased from 11 to 37 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The second method goes to a random sampling of prescriptions submitted but, to ensure a proper and adequate payment to the pharmacists, they are able in that process to have 10 per cent of their claims treated in the full processing way, with the remainder to be reimbursed by the sampling method. My understanding is that considerable thought and planning has gone into that sampling process to ensure the fairest and most reliable return to the pharmacists who choose to adopt that process. I think some other pharmacists will continue to provide their lists of prescriptions in the way they have previously done. Some honourable senators opposite have suggested that owners of small pharmacies would not be interested in investing in what they said was expensive high technology, although I understand that technology can be geared to the size of the business concerned, because there was a disadvantage for them if they did not exercise their option to go into the high technology systems of repayment.

I think it needs to be noted that about 37 per cent of pharmacists prefer to exercise their option under that process. Again a further percentage-I do not have the figures for that-will be doing their submissions under the sampling system. Those who remain will not be dramatically disadvantaged, if at all, because the more time consuming process that they will be treated with will be offset by the reduced number of claims in that full processing method, because so many other pharmacists are exercising the other two options.

The Government is very concerned to address the difficulties of the considerable backlog that had accrued over the years. Whilst I think it was reasonable to criticise that delay, I think it is not valid to continue that criticism in the face of these proposed changes that the Government has put in place precisely to deal with the problem that it has been more than aware of. So I think it would be more beneficial at this time to see the outcome of these proposed changes and to see whether the turnaround time for repayment is as the Government expects it will be, of 20 or 21 days or perhaps a few more days, for the full processing system. I would be surprised if it were not reduced to that period, given the very excellent record of repayments under the Medicare scheme. The turnaround time there is very short and very much on the predictions that the Government estimated. I do not have any sense that the Government is falsifying the turnaround time or in any way wanting to confuse people or to misrepresent what will be the facts. In fact the Government will be watching it very closely, precisely because of its concern at the delay in repayment. I think it is a very proper concern. I think the criticism that has been mounted about that delay in the past was proper and right, and I think this legislation should be acknowledged as a proper and right attempt to address that.

The final point I want to make goes to the other and very important consideration in this area of legislative change, and that is to ensure that people in need of medication are provided with that medication in a financially manageable way. We have here one of those lively tensions between sufficient and proper return to the pharmaceutical industry, to encourage development of drug manufacturing in this country and to provide sufficient research incentive for those developments to proceed and to grow in this country, and the cost to those who need medication. I suppose by way of an aside I can recall to the Senate the case of Fauldings, which has a large presence in South Australia, which has done very well over recent years with some of its pharmaceuticals. So it is perfectly possible for drug companies in Australia to be successful. At the same time that proper return to the pharmaceutical industry has to be balanced against the cost to the people in Australia who need medication.

The pharmaceutical benefits scheme has, I think, always managed to keep that balance properly in control. As well as the recognition of the changes in November 1986 that there would be considerable savings to the Government if the cost of a pharmaceutical prescription were increased for the majority of people-that is those who can afford to pay and who had very little need to attend doctors for medical treatment-those savings to government could then be put to advantage those people who are chronically ill or who had large claims for medication because of a number of sick children or, as I mentioned, because of chronic illness. The safety net provisions introduced by this Government very properly, and I think very adequately, addressed that, and will ensure that nobody will be dramatically disadvantaged financially in having to seek proper medical treatment.

So in all ways I think this legislation addresses the issues of concern in the pharmaceutical benefits area. I think it provides a very reasonable and proper balance. It is important that sufficient flexibility is allowed for continuing encouragement for industries in this area in Australia. We do not want to become an importing only country in this area. We have evidence that that does not have to be the case. At the same time, we want systems that will properly test new medications and will properly provide even very expensive medication. I again draw the Senate's attention to the example cited by Senator Puplick. It is one of a number that go to the Government's proper consideration on compassionate grounds when medications proposed in certain areas are very expensive. The Government has always acknowledged the propriety of sometimes allowing expensive medications to be provided. But it also properly says that if it does that for all medications with no constraints the growth of expenditure in this area would continue to rise and would no doubt top the $1 billion mark-a very significant and large outlay in costs for government. It properly wants to consider restraint in this area.

This piece of legislation does canvass the areas. It proposes changes that I think will address the difficulties that have existed. It will encourage a more rapid return to the pharmacists concerned and it will make sure that restraints of costs to users of pharmaceuticals are kept within reasonable bounds. For those reasons I am pleased to support this legislation.
