TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 is a piffling Bill, yet the Senate seems to have had a certain amount of indigestion getting it through. It does only three things: it updates and modernises the way in which the Government pays chemists for supplying prescriptions to people; it enlarges the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee; and it gives the Minister, unilaterally, the power to cross drugs off the pharmaceutical benefits list. It really represents the machinery by which the pharmaceutical industry can stagger through the quagmire of government negotiations that it has been going through for many years. I have been on various health committees, both in government and in opposition, when representations have been made by both pharmaceutical manufacturing companies and pharmacists when they have been in trouble year in, year out. They have argued with the Government about the administration of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I remember that, initially, it was a most generous scheme for ordinary patients, pensioners and veterans. It is a fine example of how a government can promise the world, with the best intentions in the world, but find, eventually, that it cannot deliver and so have to restrict the service.

SPEECH.PARA: Initially, a little blue book was put out and that contained an extensive range of the drugs that were available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Only a few of the drugs were printed in red. They were usually the most expensive and doctors had to be more careful in prescribing them. That was not sufficient to restrict the amount of prescribing that was done, so doctors had to apply for permission to prescribe the more expensive drugs. It got harder and harder to get permission to do that. The allowance for veterans was probably the most generous, which I think was quite normal. Veterans were entitled to all sorts of items which we used to refer to as grocery lines-Kleenex tissues, cotton wool, Aktavite and so on. Doctors used to prescribe those items, but veterans made the error of taking the items down to the pub and flogging them. One could not blame the Department for putting restrictions on those sorts of things. Eventually, the doctors had to write to departments to get permission to prescribe them.

I can remember how the pharmaceutical companies fell over themselves to get items listed on the pharmaceutical benefits list. The minute the items were listed, the doctors were smothered by a plethora of drug retailers who visited them saying, `Here is a new, modern and better item for you to prescribe'. Even the pharmacists had difficulty in keeping up with the rapid turnover in the drugs that were available under the scheme. Naturally, the costs escalated all round and the Government started to restrict the service, what the chemists could do and what the pharmaceutical benefits companies could do. The rest is just a commentary in time and space. As I have said, the Bill represents the latest mess-up in an attempt to rectify previous mess-ups.

The industry welcomes the Bill, as it does ease its present pain a little. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill, but it seeks amendments to certain clauses of it. The pharmacists are still keen to negotiate with the Government, despite their years of experience in finding that the Government is not the most congenial partner with which to work. Pharmacists, like the doctors, prostituted their profession when they mistook the Government's intentions as good. I am sure that the Government's intentions are good, but the effects of the policy are all bad. This goes back to the old proverb: `He who pays the piper calls the tune'. If the Government is paying the bill, the Government can call the tune. There is another old proverb to this effect: `That which the Government wishes to control, it first subsidises'. That is what has happened in this instance. The subsidy that the Government provided in this case became built into the chemists' economy. In other words, the chemists could not function without receiving the money. Once they were in that position, the Government could start dictating terms and conditions. As the years have passed, those terms and conditions have become progressively more stringent and chemists' incomes have been gradually squeezed. In order to survive they have had to enter into competition with supermarkets. Patients found that to get to a chemist's dispensary they had to wade through a maze of supermarket-type display trolleys and other wares that they were selling. I am sure that many honourable senators have seen how chemists go out on to the street with microphones and act like circus barkers as they advertise their wares and drum up business.

The pharmaceutical companies were also pinched to the extent that research and development left Australia. There was a time, not so long ago, when we had no capacity for research and development in the pharmaceutical area. That dangerous situation has been mentioned earlier in the debate. It has important defence connotations for Australia. I can remember that at one time the Government felt that it needed a window into the pharmaceutical industry so that it could have some sort of control over the costs of buying raw materials, manufacture and distribution. It went so far as to buy a pharmaceutical company at an exorbitant cost. After a bit of experimentation with that pharmaceutical company, the Government eventually sold it at an enormous loss. I can also remember that the Government opened up the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) which were created to produce biological products only-things such as snake and spider venoms; non-commercial type products. The law was altered so that CSL could make non-biologicals and virtually go into competition with pharmaceutical companies.

The last method of paying chemists, and there have been many over the years, was Pharmpay. That was introduced in 1985 and lasted about a year. For the last year the Government has been implementing the program that is contained in this Bill. But by the time Pharmpay became a shambles, with delayed and inaccurate payments, there were 51 million prescriptions in a gigantic backlog. The delays in payments to chemists were quite disastrous to their businesses. Chemists have to pay for their stock as they get it. They get discounts from pharmaceutical companies if they pay their bills within a certain time. But, of course, if the Government has not paid the chemists they are unable to get the discounts. I might add that the Government does not take account of the discount a chemist gets when it works out the price that it will pay the chemist for pharmaceuticals. The chemists found that, in order to keep their stocks alive, they had to obtain a bank overdraft. They had to pay interest on the overdraft and, of course, that interest was not taken into account when the Government worked out how much it would pay the chemists. The chemists found that when the delays in payment went over one, two or three months-I think that 102 days was the championship date that was reached-the banks tightened up on their overdraft ceiling and the cheques of some chemists bounced, which must have been very embarrassing for them. Some of them actually went broke. I say to the Minister: The Government should pay its bills promptly. A Bill which is designed to ensure that is before the House. If the Government does not pay its bill on time, at least it should pay interest on the money that it owes.

What the Government did to extricate itself from the problems it was experiencing with the big backlog was to start an averaging payment method for prescriptions. This meant that it looked at the last three or four months of a chemist's accounts that were reasonably accurate. It took his prescriptions, threw them in the air and worked out an average amount which he would be paid. This method was very inaccurate and one can bet that mistakes were made. It would be very disadvantageous for a chemist to have, for example, a seasonal business.

This Bill proposes a new method of payment which is combined with the old ones. Fortunately, chemists are rapidly becoming computerised. They can use the electronic data transfer method which is the centrepiece of the Government's solution and the centrepiece of this Bill. The preferred method is called the claims transmission service (CTS), which uses compatible floppy disks. In other words, the chemist has a disk on his computer that is compatible with that of the Government and this will enhance the rapidity with which he can work out his claims. To encourage the chemist, the Government is willing to pay 2.5c a script for the next two years provided that chemists have joined the CTS by 1 November. As that date has already passed I hope they are given a little longer because there are 5,000 pharmacies in Australia. When the Bill was introduced I think about 1,700 pharmacies had decided to join. From what I have heard, an avalanche of chemists have tried to get into the system so perhaps the number is now nearer 5,000. But it would be a little unfair, even if the Government had been running this system for about a year, if all the chemists were not given a chance to join. One could understand how difficult it would be for a small pharmacy when the chemist, who does not really understand computers, has to be talked into installing one. In an ordinary little pharmacy the incentive of receiving 2.5c a prescription would just pay for the running and maintenance of the floppy disks. So the chemist will not be making a profit out of the incentive that is offered to him.

The second payment system option offered is called the alternative method whereby the Government guarantees that it will pay pharmacists within 25 days. This system involves random sampling, and again one can bet that that system will have mistakes in it. That is the measure the Opposition hopes to amend by inserting a sunset clause in the legislation. Thus the alternative method of random sampling will cease to be in effect at the end of two years.

The third payment method is the old manual method which has been in existence since time immemorial. The Government says it will pay pharmacists within 30 days. I presume the Government feels that it will be able to pay them within 30 days because the load will have been taken off it with most of the work going on floppy disks. This method of payment will still be dicey though.

The important thing in all of the three systems of payment the Government will allow is that the scripts will still have to be sorted and numbered. In other words, the chemist will still be stuck with the same amount of work even though he will have to feed everything on to floppy disks. In all, the chemist's costs have increased.

With the introduction of this CTS system the Government says that it will save about $6m, but to make sure it does-I have heard this but I have not had it confirmed-it will close the Adelaide and Hobart processing centres. That means the Government will lose some flexibility in its processing, particularly in trying to overcome log-jams and strikes for example. In other words, claims will no longer be able to be redirected through other States when there are problems with the centralised computers.

The second part of the Bill deals with the reorganisation of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). Again this measure is supposed to reduce costs; It has nothing to do with better health or more efficiency-although that is what the Government claims. Our total health costs are over $8,000m, the pharmaceutical section of which is $800m, which the Government expects to rise to $970m. However, with the introduction of floppy disks and the restructuring of the PBAC, it will save $100m; and so this measure will cost $870m. I do not often quote a lot of figures but the pertinent figures are that pharmaceutical benefits are costing $800m this year and they will cost $870m next year. It is very good bureaucratic logic to say that we expect to save $100m and yet we wind up spending an extra $70m.
The Board will be increased from eight to 11 members by adding three doctors. It will wind up with 10 doctors and one dentist and this is supposed to create more efficiency.

TALK.START.PARA: —One pharmacist.

—One pharmacist. The PBAC secretariat will be enlarged and that, I suppose, is the traditional Public Service way of saving money. Allegedly this provision will mean better investigation of the worth of drugs and it will be easier to hire consultants to pursue the Government's intentions. The Government's intention is to apply a cost-benefit analysis to procedures and to the distribution and new listing of drugs. Other speakers in this debate have quoted the second reading speech of the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The obligation-
of the PBAC-
to consider comparative effectiveness and cost will require the PBAC to give consideration to alternative forms of treatment, for example surgery . . .

A considerable amount of attention has been devoted in this debate to just that section of the legislation, and rightly so. This kind of consideration often takes place in the medical, surgical or any other treatment of patients, but at a level between the doctor and the patient. And that is right, too, because that is the proper place to consider the costs of treatment and the most suitable treatment for a patient. This legislation is transferring that negotiation to the Government and the pharmacists, and once again the Government has the wrong bulls in the ring. In this case it has itself and the pharmacists in the ring battling it out and it should really be the doctors and the patients who are battling it out. The same thing happened with the doctors' negotiations. The Government wound up with the doctors and patients battling in the ring when the real battle should have been between the Government and the medical insurance companies. We are again going down the wrong path and I can assure the Government that this section of the legislation will cause trouble in the practical implementation of the Bill. The Government will decide the cost-benefit analysis to the patient and one can bet the Government will not consider the patients as much as the doctors would. By implementing this part of the Act, the Government will be virtually coercing doctors into using the cheapest forms of treatment on patients when perhaps other forms of treatment might be better.

Finally, the Bill gives the Minister the power to remove pharmaceuticals from the list unilaterally. Obviously this is to give the Minister power to cut government expenditure in an emergency when he sees fit. It may be a necessary power. The Opposition will move an amendment to the effect that the reasons for doing this sort of thing must be tabled and the measure is to be handled much as a regulation is handled in other areas. I do not know whether the Parliament will have the power to reverse the Minister's decision if he has gone wrong. Nevertheless, I do not feel as apprehensive about that as do other people, because the Minister has responsibilities to his Party, his Caucus and everybody else and he is unlikely to do anything stupid. As a matter of fact, I think it is often a lot easier to get at a Minister than to get at autonomous government departments.

One thing that I would say about this Bill and the restrictions it is putting on the the pharmaceutical benefits system is that very rich people will still be able to go outside the system and purchase their health care. However, the health care of poorer people is being whittled away. This is common to what is happening under this Government at the moment-that is, the Government is making bigger divisions between the rich and the poor than have ever been seen before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their very informed contributions to this debate. A number of views have been put forward which really are alternative strategies to the one the Government has decided to undertake. Therefore, I do not think there is any point in my entering into a full-scale debate on the different views that have been put forward. But a number of specific issues have been raised and I will comment on them briefly. Honourable senators who wish to raise more specific matters may do so during the committee stage. Senator Peter Baume raised what he saw as a contradiction between the requirement for the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) to consider cost-effectiveness and the industry package announced by Dr Blewett and Senator Button on 13 September.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Government's view there is no contradiction. The details of that arrangement are still being sorted out. The Government is committed to a new policy of allowing price increases where the pharmaceutical industry is prepared to increase its Australian activity. It is not intended that the PBAC will take account of any price premiums for Australian activity when comparing the costs of alternative therapists. Senator Baume, pursuing his interest in the PBAC, wanted to know how it would look at cost effectiveness and how therapeutic equivalence would be determined. A professional committee will be established for that purpose. There is a budget for consultants and that budget is being increased significantly. The cost-effectiveness of drugs is a very technical area. In many respects, that area is in its infancy in Australia. In the Government's view, it is better to have those matters determined by a professional body than by a committee of Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The doctors have been doing it for years.

—We are still referring the matter to a professional committee. We are not taking over from the professionals in that respect. The legislation before us deliberately takes a broad view of cost-effectiveness, which is intended--
—Are you saying that you will leave it to that committee and you are not quite sure how it will work out equivalence?

—What I am saying is that we regard it as a matter for professionals. It will not be a political decision; we will take advice from that committee. The broad view of cost-effectiveness is intended to recognise those circumstances where drugs are cheaper and better therapy than surgery and take account of quality of life issues and also side effects. The committee will comprise eminent professionals, predominantly medical practitioners, as Senator Peter Baume and Senator Sheil will be pleased to hear.
—I think they know better than to trust them explicitly.

—I am sure that Senator Puplick would agree that there is always a bit of solidarity when it comes to medical practitioners. Those professionals will be expected to take full account of the therapeutic equivalence of alternative forms of treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to respond to a couple of points that were raised by Senator Sheil. The honourable senator raised the matter of the 1 November deadlines on the claims transmission service incentive of 2.5c. I would like Senator Sheil and other honourable senators to be aware that the Department of Community Services and Health wrote to all pharmacists four months ago drawing their attention to the offer. There has been extensive publicity of the offer in trade journals. In fact, 44 per cent of pharmacists have taken it up. Most other pharmacists do not have computers. Their business may be too small and, therefore, they really are not relevant. I will leave other specific comments to the committee stage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Pharmaceutical benefits).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats wish to move an amendment to clause 4 of the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. We are concerned that the Minister, under clause 4 as printed in the Bill, may make a declaration under proposed new sub-section (2ab) which says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister shall have regard to any view previously expressed . . .

The Minister is not required actively to seek the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. The Australian Democrats feel that if the Minister wishes to remove a drug from the schedule, he should actively seek that advice. We have been persuaded by the Opposition that in addition to seeking that advice, that that advice, together with the notification, should be laid before each House of the Parliament.

The Opposition intends to move an amendment, that the Committee, in making reviews, should give consideration to the items covered on page 7 of the Bill under proposed new sub-section 101 (3a) in clause 8 (1). The Australian Democrats are not persuaded that it is necessary to append those conditions to the provisions of clause 4 because, as the various conditions in the clauses must be read together, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee would have to give consideration to those items mentioned in clause 8 (1), namely the effectiveness and cost of therapy, in providing that advice to the Minister. Therefore, I move:
(1) Page 2, clause 4, paragraph (a), leave out proposed new subsection 85 (2ab), insert the following subsections:
``(2ab) Before making a declaration under subsection (2aa), the Minister shall obtain the advice in writing of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee in relation to the proposed declaration.
``(2ac) An advice under subsection (2ab) shall be laid before each House of the Parliament with the declaration under subsection (2aa) to which the advice relates.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I wish to move an amendment to the amendment that Senator Coulter has just put before the Committee. Our amendment seeks to insert a new sub-section (2aba) in the form which has been circulated in the chamber. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (No. 1), after proposed new subsection 85 (2ab), insert the following subsection:
``(2aba) In providing advice under subsection (2ab) the Committee shall have regard, as far as practicable, to the matters referred to in subsection 101 (3a).''

I will come back to that amendment in a moment. We agree with the two new sub-sections which are proposed in the amendment which Senator Coulter has just moved; namely, that in relation to the Minister's pending decision to remove an item from the list, he should actively seek the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) and that that advice, having been sought and provided to the Minister, should be tabled in the Parliament.

This is important because the Bill provides that the Minister's determination is reviewable by Parliament because it is a regulation. In other words, the Parliament will be able to disallow the Minister's determination once it has been made. We are saying that the Minister should table the advice he has received from the PBAC in order to allow the Parliament to make a more informed determination about whether there are grounds, on the basis of good scientific and economic advice, for the Minister's decision to be overturned. But to bring about this situation we believe that there are two conditions precedent. The first is that there must be contemporary evidence. The Bill seeks to insert in section 85 of the principal Act a new provision (2ab), which reads:

Before making a declaration . . . the Minister shall have regard to any view previously expressed to the Minister for the purposes of this Part by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee and relating to the drug or medicinal preparation, or the class of drugs and medicinal preparations, as the case may be.

Senator Crowley attempted to say that this means that there will be in the Minister's hands not only a view which was previously expressed but also a statement of the current position. In fact, there is nothing in the legislation to support that view. Senator Crowley's view is erroneous. The legislation refers quite clearly to `any view previously expressed'. That view may have been that the drug should have been listed in the first place-that may be the last time that the matter has come from the PBAC to the Minister-or that it should be sustained on a list. That advice may be several years old.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are talking about extending the patent life to 20 years.

—Indeed, as my colleague rightly points out, if one looks at the announcement made jointly by the Minister for Community Services and Health and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce one sees that one of the things that were to be done allegedly to support the Australian pharmaceutical manufacturing industry was an extension in the patent life of the drugs concerned. Therefore, this pharmaceutical which may have had an extended patent life may have last been the subject of advice from the PBAC to the Minister quite some years before. This amendment says that the Minister shall obtain advice on the current position when contemplating the potential delisting of a drug.

SPEECH.PARA: There may be another time element of importance. I refer to the time element that may elapse between either House getting round to dealing with the question of a disallowance. After all, if a drug is delisted by the Minister, it may be done at a time when Parliament is not meeting; it may be a recess period. It may well be that, by the time all the processes involving the 15 sitting days which are referred to in the Acts Interpretation Act dealing with disallowance of regulations elapse, one might be looking at a passage of three or four months or longer. Issues will arise in terms of delays and the consequences of the delisting of the drug if that delisting is subsequently disallowed in the period in which it was disallowed and before the Minister's determination was overturned. Obviously matters arise in that regard. However, we believe that there is a second condition precedent which should be part of this amendment before the tabling of the advice is of maximum effect in advising and informing the Parliament about its decisions on the delisting of a pharmaceutical. As a result we have moved to insert a further sub-section 2 (aba), which reads:
In providing advice under subsection (2ab) the Committee shall have regard, as far as practicable, to the matters referred to in subsection 101 (3a).
Sub-section 101 (3a) which is being inserted by clause 8 of this Bill, reads as follows:

For the purpose of deciding whether to recommend to the Minister that a drug or medicinal preparation, or a class of drugs and medicinal preparations, be made available as pharmaceutical benefits under this Part, the Committee shall give consideration to the effectiveness and cost of therapy involving the use of the drug, preparation or class, including by comparing the effectiveness and cost of that therapy with that of alternative therapies, whether or not involving the use of other drugs or preparations.

Senator Coulter is saying that the Committee will take that into account and will specify, in the advice that it gives to the Minister which the Minister must table, all those things. We do not believe that to be the case. We do not believe that, in the absence of the clear statutory requirement to do those things, the PBAC will necessarily do them.

There are at least three elements in sub-section 101 (3a). Firstly, they go to effectiveness, secondly, to the cost of therapy, and, thirdly, they include comparing the effectiveness and cost of that therapy with that of alternative therapies. The Minister may well have a particular preparation in mind. He may say to the PBAC, `I want you to give me advice on the delisting of this drug and whether as a method of reducing costs this drug can be removed from the list'. Or he may say, `I want you to give me advice whether this preparation is preferable in that there is an alternative preparation which is made in Australia', an alternative preparation made by a company with which the Government has entered into some good citizenship agreement, which is currently the vogue in corporate relationships between the Government and various manufacturers. The Minister may say to the Committee, `Please give me advice on the following matters . . .' The Committee renders advice on those matters, because it takes the Minister's instructions, and that advice is then tabled, but that advice does not necessarily require the Committee to address itself to the matters specifically set out in sub-section 101 (3a).

Senator Coulter says, `Of course, they will do that'. But there is no empirical evidence to demonstrate that a committee, which at the end of the day is subject to some degree of ministerial influence, if presented by the Minister with a request to advise him on matter X, will necessarily also advise him on matters Y and Z simply because in other circumstances it is required to do so. That is the way in which advisory committees to government frequently operate. If the Minister says, `In terms of reducing the overall cost of treatment of disease A, is it desirable to remove a particular preparation from the list-yes or no?'-and the Committee responds to the Minister on the question the Minister has posed, we will not have the sort of evidence which the other purport of the Australian Democrats' amendment would put before the Parliament to allow us to address the possible disallowance of the regulation which the Minister has made. We are simply saying that, among other things, it should be clearly understood that the Committee shall have regard so far as practicable to the matters which are referred to in the amendment which is otherwise being proposed to section 101 of the principal Act.

If Senator Coulter is saying that he feels that will be covered and is not necessary, I say to him with the greatest of good will that it is surely better to overstate the proposition than to run the risk that by not stating it we will not have the evidence that we require. If he believes that the matter is covered, simply to specify it by adding one more clause to the Bill seems to me to do no harm. Therefore, if Senator Coulter is right by adding the clause we in no way weaken or unnecessarily complicate the matter. But if Senator Coulter is wrong and I am right, the common objective that we have to get the evidence before us is well served by making the additional requirement. It may well be that Senator Coulter is right. If he is right, adding this clause in no way detracts from the point that he has been putting forward. If by chance he is wrong and I am right, adding the clause will achieve the objective which I believe we both want to see achieved-that is to say, there should be current evidence called for, it should be comprehensive in terms of the issues which it addresses and it should be laid before the Parliament. Therefore, I press the amendment to the Democrat amendment, which I have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would not be moving in this direction if I believed I were wrong. Therefore I do believe that I am right. Furthermore, I believe that legislation should not be made unnecessarily complex by adding unnecessary clauses. In answer to the points made by Senator Puplick, I point out that we are dealing with sub-section (2aa) which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, by instrument in writing, declare that a drug or medicinal preparation, or a class of drugs and medicinal preparations, shall cease to be a drug or medicinal preparation . . .

The decision which the Minister is making is to remove a drug from the list. The effect of the amendment, which I have moved, is that before making a declaration the Minister shall obtain the advice in writing of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) in relation to the proposed declaration. It is quite clear that the Minister shall obtain the advice in relation to whether the drug is on the list. Clearly, clause 8 (1) (b) (3a) to which I have already referred says:
For the purpose of deciding whether to recommend to the Minister that a drug or medicinal preparation, or a class of drug and medicinal preparations, be made available-
that is, whether it is on the list or not-
as pharmaceutical benefits under this Part, the Committee shall give consideration to . . .

It then sets out the matters which will be considered by that Committee in giving that advice to the Minister. It seems to me to be absolutely clear that the amendment, as moved by the Australian Democrats, achieves exactly the purpose which the Opposition also wishes to achieve, but without the cumbrous addition of words which are already in the Bill and the interpretation of which is abundantly clear.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats and therefore we do not accept the refinement of it moved by Senator Puplick. I remind honourable senators that the main purpose of clause 4 is to speed up decision-making, not to ignore professional advice. Circumstances can arise where it is desirable to remove the drug quickly-for example, where a company unilaterally raises prices to unacceptable levels and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) has previously advised that there are adequate substitutes available on the list. Another example is where doubts arise about the safety of a drug and urgent action is required in advance of a formal PBAC meeting. I remind honourable senators that the Committee meets only three times a year. Obviously, a Minister would not make such a decision without having professional advice which can be made available to him readily and quickly through his departmental advisers. But to establish the procedure of having to bring the matter to the Senate and having to have the right number of sitting days before a disallowance motion can be dealt with, could really be quite injurious to public health under certain circumstances. I also remind honourable senators of the very sensible remarks made by Senator Sheil, who has not been able to stay in the chamber at this point, to the effect that a Minister would be very ill advised to make the wrong decision under these circumstances. It is not as if such a decision would go unnoticed or uncomplained of. Obviously any Minister would get sensible advice before he took the decision, but we are simply seeking to provide the opportunity for the Minister to act quickly when it is in the public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health (Senator Ryan) and to Senator Coulter. We have approached this debate in an effort to try to help with the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2). I remind the Minister that we are supporting the legislation and that the views that we have expressed in relation to the pharmaceutical industry have been expressed with some care because we really are concerned about an industry which is contracting and which has been dying. The questions before the Senate now are questions of life and death for the pharmaceutical industry. I remind the Committee that we are dealing with a situation where the Government is in a position of a monopsonistic purchaser. It has monopsony power over the market and that has put the industry in a most invidious position for some decades now. The Minister talks about the need to move quickly, but it has been known for the Department of Community Services and Health to be vindictive in relation to the pharmaceutical manufacturing industry. There are examples of that. If the Minister is required to table an instrument within X sitting days-or within five sitting days or whatever it might be--
—It is 15 if it is the same as the regulation. It could go over a parliamentary recess. It could be quite a long period.

—A disallowance process, even when moved, may take 15 sitting days which, of itself, may be a couple of months. It is quite possible for the Department to say to a pharmaceutical manufacturer, `Well, it may well be disallowed. But we will have punished you. You will have been out of the market for two or three months before you can get your disallowance through'. It is not really very satisfying to say that the PBAC, as it has existed and with the functions it has had in the past, has met three times a year, and that is the way it will be. It is a new Committee, it has new functions and a new role. For it to meet three times a year will not be enough; it should meet as often as is required in order to discharge its new functions. If that requires a meeting at short notice to deal with these kinds of urgent situations, I would expect it so to meet.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I came into this place I served on one of the therapeutic goods advisory committees. These committees met far too seldom to be of any effect at that time. I come back now to Senator Coulter's point. I do not regard this Committee as a debating society-I am not trying to win a point; it is not a question of winning a point. It is a question of pursuing what Senator Coulter is trying to achieve for the industry. We happen to think that what he is trying to achieve is important and we will support the amendment. I say to the honourable senator that if by some chance he has not been right, the industry will have this Hansard before it. It will examine it and will be very disappointed if it finds that the honourable senator has not been able to achieve what he has just told us he wishes to achieve. This was the point made by my colleague Senator Puplick. Let me consider the points that Senator Puplick has made. Are we disagreeing with Senator Coulter? Of course we are not. We are trying to pursue and achieve the same purpose. Senator Coulter knows that we support his amendment. He knows that we are pursuing a common purpose. We have no objection at all to the substance of his amendment. We are trying to make explicit a matter which at the moment is not explicit and which Senator Coulter believes, in good faith, is implicit in the way the Bill is constructed. I understand his argument. He might be right, but I put to the honourable senator that if he is right and these extra words are added, what harm has been done? If the words are not necessary, as he says they are not, no harm has been done. There has been no derogation from the purpose he is seeking to achieve. That purpose will still be achieved. One might say that the amendment is belt and braces, but at least the purpose will still be achieved. It would do no harm whatsoever. It would make quite explicit and definite what we have said is necessary and what Senator Coulter thinks would happen anyhow.

On the other hand, if the extra words were necessary and this Committee proceeded not to include them, it might open up the kind of weakness to which Senator Puplick has referred and take away from what Senator Coulter has been trying to achieve. The industry is very concerned that it gets a fair go. That is all it wants. If the Minister is to take drugs, substances or classes of substances off the list, so be it, provided the process has been fair. I put it to Senator Coulter that we are not trying to score points. Both of us are trying to achieve a purpose. We suggest to Senator Coulter that there is nothing to be lost and a little insurance to be gained from adding these extra words and making quite explicit the purpose which we both seek to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister, in reply to Senator Puplick and Senator Coulter, said that the Minister for Community Services and Health would be taking the advice only of experts, that is, officers of the Department, and would, therefore, be taking only responsible and correct advice. As Senator Baume has said, in the past we have witnessed advice by officers of the Department that has not been accurate, nor in the best interests of patients. I give a couple of examples. Treatment for the removal of warts was removed from the schedule of fees. Departmental officers must have advised the Minister, with the best will in the world surely, that such a measure would be all right. With ordinary warts, that may have been the case but, as Senator Coulter is probably aware, there are also genital warts. The Department has now acknowledged that this is not the correct way to go and negotiations are taking place to overcome the problem which has been pointed out to the Department and to the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Another example was when, on advice obviously given to the Minister by departmental officers-the so-called experts-the Minister decided, I think it was in the mini-Budget, that physicians should have only one consultation and two follow-ups. Senator Baume, in Estimates committee hearings, pointed out at least 20 illnesses which could not be appropriately treated by just one consultation by a physician and two follow-ups. Dr De Souza, a departmental officer, agreed with him. Again, the Minister has had to renegotiate with the doctors.

So we have had very recent experience of departmental advice-I presume that the Minister sought advice from the Department in this area and that he did not make those decisions off the top of his head-being far from good advice. The advice was dreadful. This has been admitted by the Minister who is now renegotiating the schedule fee with the physicians. So there have been instances of departmental officers not giving the best advice in the world. It is for that reason that I agree with Senator Baume that we need the extra insurance which the Opposition's amendment to the Democrats' amendment gives us. I believe that it is essential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a further point in response to the Minister's remark that the Minister may seek advice from departmental officers. I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that this Bill also seeks to increase the size of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee and to give the Minister the power to set up sub-committees. Presumably, one part of the Bill, at least, recognises that the Minister needs even wider advice. On this point I would certainly accept what Senator Baume has said. I see no reason at all why the Minister should not call the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee together quickly if he or she needs rapid advice. That is far preferable to the Minister simply seeking internal departmental advice.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That Senator Puplick's amendment to Senator Coulter's amendment be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that Senator Coulter's amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an amendment to clause 6 in the form which has been circulated in the chamber. The purport of this amendment is to introduce in effect a sunset clause, nominating 30 June 1989 as the date at which the Pharmpay arrangement, which works upon the principle of reimbursing pharmacists who have submitted material to the Department of Community Services and Health using the random sampling method which is provided as one of three alternatives under the new Pharmpay arrangements, shall terminate. Of course, that does not mean `shall be permanently terminated'. It simply means that before 30 June 1989 the Government must come back to the Parliament and demonstrate to the Parliament that the system should be maintained or that the system should be properly be allowed to conclude on that date because it has proved unsatisfactory as a method of dealing with payments under the Pharmpay scheme using the random sampling method.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to traverse all the ground which I traversed in my speech on the second reading, or indeed to refer people again to the speech made in the House of Representatives by Mr Lamb, an Australian Labor Party member, in which he drew attention to the errors which can easily arise with the random sampling method. What we are saying is that this is a new method of making payments to pharmacists. It is an untried method. We have no objection to trying it. We are perfectly prepared to allow it to be tried. However, we think that it should be reviewed before 30 June 1989. If the review demonstrates that the scheme is worth maintaining, the Parliament will be persuaded and the sunset clause can simply be deleted from the legislation. If, however, it appears that there are errors in this scheme or that the scheme is being abused in some systematic fashion which is not capable of being tidied up relatively easily, this clause will have the effect of terminating that method of payment and leaving simply the two alternative methods, that is, the modem or floppy disk submission of information or the complete analysis and payment on all of the scripts which have been submitted under the Pharmpay scheme in the way in which that currently operates. Again, this is simply a matter of putting some internal policing arrangements into the Act to see whether the new system, which we are certainly prepared to trial, will work effectively, and to provide a mechanism whereby, if it does not work effectively, it will be terminated and not left as an open-ended running problem for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick, you appeared to be talking about your amendment (2) but not your amendment (1). As (1) is consequential upon (2), it may be convenient for you to seek leave to move them together.
—by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5, clause 6, line 21, proposed subsection 99aac (2), leave out ``An'', insert ``Subject to subsection (6) an''.
(2) Page 5, clause 6, at end of proposed section 99aac, add the following new subsection:
`` `(6) No alternative payment election has effect on or after 30 June 1989.'.''.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 8 of this Bill gives the Minister the power to appoint extra members to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. Proposed new section 101 (2) (b) states that `not more than 3 medical practitioners in addition to the medical practitioners referred to in paragraph (1) (b)' may be so appointed. The effect of the amendment which the Australian Democrats wish to move is to include among those three at least one who is a member of the Doctors' Reform Society. From the humour being expressed on my right, I take it there are some who may not agree with the stance that is often taken by the Doctors' Reform Society. In recent years among the medical fraternity there has been an increasingly wide spread of views in relation to the types of medical practice offered, the organisation of medical practice as regard private and government health provisions, and also the place of medical care in the whole social arrangement. I think it is also fairly widely accepted that in the past the medical profession has been, and has been conceived to be, a somewhat conservative body of people. I should know that, being one of those people myself. As a matter of fact, just this afternoon during Question Time I heard Senator Walsh, on behalf of the Government, being extremely critical of the Australian Medical Association. It would seem extremely appropriate, therefore, to include one of the better known groups of medical practitioners which over the years has been very active and has had a lot to say on this very issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment which was circulated last night has been slightly modified, and a revised version has been circulated this evening. There are two reasons for the revision. The first relates to the fact that the earlier version was open to an interpretation in which, if the Minister chose to appoint medical practitioners one at a time, each of those appointees should come from the Doctors' Reform Society. So, eventually we could finish up with three members from the Doctors' Reform Society on the Committee, and that was certainly not intended. The second slight modification arose because the Doctors' Reform Society is shortly to become an incorporated body. It was clearly necessary to define both the Doctors' Reform Society and the Doctors' Reform Society Incorporated, lest they be interpreted as two separate organisations. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that clause 8, as amended, be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman-

SPEECH.PARA: . . . alternative therapies, whether or not involving the use of other drugs or preparations . . .

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that it is inappropriate for Senator Walters to pursue this line of action. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will require the PBAC to give consideration to alternative forms of treatment, for example surgery . . .

DEBATE.TITLE: EGG INDUSTRY RESEARCH (HEN QUOTA) LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —To many honourable senators the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Amendment Bill 1987 may not be considered to be very serious, but to the egg producing industry around Australia it is important. I should on this occasion reminisce to the extent that I do on most occasions when we discuss poultry Bills and remember one of our colleagues who was an inbuilt expert on the poultry industry for some years in this chamber. We miss his contribution at a time such as this. The amending Bill is necessary because of the inadequate drafting of the original Bills passed earlier this year. The aim of the original legislative package was to permit the continuation of a levy on egg producers to fund industry research. The earlier Bills facilitated the collection of levies from producers which will amount to $250,000 and which will be matched by the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The egg industry in Australia is a $200m per annum industry, with Australians consuming almost 180 million dozen eggs annually. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in 1984-85 there were 863 agricultural establishments engaged in the egg industry, and spread across every State and Territory in Australia. Egg sales have decreased by about 2 per cent in the last five years, although this has been partly offset by increased sales of manufactured egg products during that time. The reduction is due, at least in part, to the real or imagined concern, promoted by nutritionists, about the cholesterol content of eggs. In response, the egg industry commissioned a $2m national advertising campaign aimed at increasing egg consumption. This co-ordinated effort represents a welcome change from the previous fragmentation of State-oriented campaigns. Furthermore, our egg producers have begun to look at developing export markets. In September last year, the industry was successful in negotiating a $15m contract to supply egg products to Japan. The contract for 8,000 tonnes of separated products from 8 million dozen eggs was won over competition from subsidised products from the European Community and the United States. This contract was something of a landmark in export sales because it represented a profitable return rather than simply the disposal of a surplus from the domestic market.

The Opposition is strongly supportive of research which increases the competitiveness of rural industries. For instance, technological advance has led to greater automation in the feeding, water supply, temperature and lighting in poultry sheds. The handling of poultry in Australia rates highly with any in the world. It is precisely these technological advances that will necessitate and, I hope, encourage our egg producers to look more keenly at expanding our export markets. The Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we are aware, the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Amendment Bill 1987 comes before us because it is necessary to rectify some anomalies in the principal Act-the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Act 1987-which passed through the Senate in June of this year. Honourable senators have been informed by the Government that these anomalies were discovered at the time of the principal Act's passage through the Senate but, because of the double dissolution of the Parliament, there was no opportunity for the Government to make the necessary amendments at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation seeks to establish clearly that the levy, which was applied by the principal Act, applies to what are called operative hen quotas-that is actual hen keeping entitlements-and addresses the industry's concern that the provisions defining the application of the levy may not, in the principal Act, have catered for some variations in State and Territory hen quota practices. The Australian Democrats support this amending legislation as it is necessary for the smooth operation of the principal Act which we supported in June of this year.

I now refer to some of the comments which I made in supporting the original Bill on 4 June when I took the opportunity of speaking briefly on some important issues relating to the egg industry. These were the continuing rationalisation of the industry, research marketing and export and product development. I take this opportunity to address again the latter of these issues, that is, product development. In the light of the recent chemical residue crisis which has occurred since the passage of the first Bill, and in the interests of the health of the consumer and the welfare of the resource-in this case the hens-I was pleased to note the encouragement given to product development in the area of free range eggs by the Australian Egg Marketing Council which, in its manual, states:

Free range eggs can command a premium over ``standard'' eggs, which appeal to that segment of consumers believing that free range eggs are nutritionally, visually and taste-superior. Free range eggs are already marketed by most of the State egg boards and indications are that sales are largely incremental.

If more producers went in for free range poultry farming they would find, as was suggested by the Egg Marketing Council in its manual, a ready and fast growing market for their produce. The other area of the industry which should be researched and developed-of course research and development is one area to which the levy will be applied with the passage of this legislation-and which would also command a premium over standard eggs is eggs which are free of the various chemicals and unwelcome additives that are a feature of modern egg production. Indeed they are a feature of most modern agricultural production in general. The Australian Democrats would like to see at least some of the funds from this levy going into research in that area. There is no doubt that consumers here and overseas will increasingly demand, now and in the future, chemical free and unpolluted food. I would encourage the industry and governments to prepare for this demand now. As I said initially, the Australian Democrats support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity today to speak on the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Amendment Bill 1987. I think Senator Archer has already mentioned that the purpose of this Bill is to impose a levy on hen quotas for the purposes of research. This matter has been discussed both in this place and in the other place so I do not wish to labour the point. However, I would like to make some comments on the egg and poultry industries. Recently I had the pleasure of addressing the seventh Australian Poultry and Feed Convention in Sydney and meeting with a great many people associated with both the egg and chicken meat industries. As I told the convention-I repeat it again tonight-I believe that the industry is one of the most efficient, technology oriented industries operating in Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: The poultry industry has been described as a truly remarkable exercise in organisation, market development and application of technology in animal production, and I would support that view. When one considers the year round availability of fresh eggs at an affordable price and in a variety of sizes, the consumer has reason to be thankful to the producers-both bird and human-and also to those involved in the administration side.

The industry is not without its controversies. In recent years, particularly in New South Wales, we have had the very sorry experience of so-called rebel producers wishing to work outside the New South Wales Egg Corporation and this has resulted in court action, disturbing scenes of police raids and angry producers both within and outside the levy system.

One can always argue the merits of deregulation of a system but it is important to realise that the egg industry, perhaps more than many other farming enterprises, is composed of a great percentage of small family concerns. There is a great deal of vertical integration, both in the egg and chicken meat industries, and it is important that they be protected and that their investment in the industry is not put at risk by fluctuations in production that might otherwise occur.

The other contentious issue that surrounds the industry is the intensive nature of its production. The egg industry has responded well over past decades to the community's demand for eggs in bountiful supply at a cheap cost. It has done this to some extent at the expense of the comfort of the birds involved in the industry. This, of course, has attracted the interest and concern of animal activist groups which, over the years, have targeted intensive poultry producers for physical and verbal abuse, vandalism and public criticism. The animal activist often lives in a utopian dreamland and his picture of the happy farm is mother hens and chickens running around scratching for food, being fed by the farmer's wife who, wearing a bountiful apron, also goes around the farm collecting eggs from happy little hens. In children's story books the hens are invariably white, the eggs are also big brown ones and everybody is happy.

Of course in real life that situation cannot exist and even in a free range system, to which Senator Powell has just referred and to which I will come back in a minute, what can often happen is that the free range bird is liable to fall prey to foxes, stray dogs and feral cats. If hens are contained in any area it is often dusty and filthy in dry weather and boggy and filthy in wet weather. Often there is no drenching program, no dropping collection system and the lovely clean egg that is pictured in the story book is turned into a filth covered mess. I ask Senator Powell what she was on about in her speech because her picture of a little farm is not quite what it is in reality.

I am a member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare of which you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are the new Chairman. This is my first opportunity of congratulating you on your appointment as Chairman of that Committee. It is a worthy appointment. You are following former Senator Georges, who did a great deal for that Committee, and I am quite sure that you will fill his boots in a most admirable manner. Probably you will go on to bigger and better things in the Australian Labor Party. I wish you well in that position. I am only too well aware, as I am quite sure you are, sir, of the arguments put forward in support of and in opposition to intensive animal production, particularly poultry and egg production. However, I abhor very strongly the actions of groups such as Action for Animals, who break into properties and steal. They do not even have the courage of their convictions by publicly saying who they are. They do these things in a cowardly and anonymous fashion, abusing people's privacy. I will quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 November 1987. A group broke into Wagners Poultry Enterprises. The article says:
The group, which called itself Action for Animals, has struck several times in the past year.
It claimed the chickens had been released from ``Wagners poultry prison and would live out the rest of their lives in peace''.
An Animal Liberation co-ordinator, Ms Patty Mark, said the group was not associated with ALV, but admitted her support of the protest.

I do not think that that sort of action will do anything for the welfare of animals, enabling them to live in a happier environment than they do now. I hope that this sort of action, which is very common overseas, does not proliferate here in Australia. I am hopeful that with the advent of the Animal Welfare Committee, people who are opposed to any industry involving animals will be able to discuss their objections in a rational and logical manner. I am disappointed that some people involved with animal liberation have applauded the vandalism of groups such as Action for Animals. It does their cause and the entire animal welfare debate little good when they take the law into their own hands.

There is no doubt that there is controversy surrounding intensive egg production, just as there is dispute about other issues, such as animals in science or live sheep exports. Surely, however, we have the maturity and ability to sit together as responsible human beings to talk out these problems and not act as vigilante groups resorting to violence and abuse of privacy.

I will return to the legislation, now that I have had my little say on the matter that Senator Powell talked about. The money that will be collected through this legislation may well help to overcome some of the objections to the intensive egg industry. Research may find more efficient and acceptable means of producing eggs in sufficient quantities for everyone to enjoy at an affordable price. I support the legislation, as does the Opposition. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to delay the passage of the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 October.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 6, clause 8, definition of ``asset re-valuation dividend'' in proposed subsection 46e (1), line 13, leave out ``4 June 1987'', insert ``23 September 1987''.
(2) Page 8, clause 8, proposed paragraph 46e (6) (a), line 12, leave out ``4 June 1987'', insert ``23 September 1987''.

As the Committee will recognise, these amendments will remove the retroactive impact of this latest example of government by Press release. It is self-evident that the details of this legislation are different in some matters of moment from the announcement made on, as I recall it, 4 June-prior to the election and during the last Parliament-when the Government first said that it intended to introduce this legislation.

The Opposition has no objection to the thrust of the legislation. There are some matters of concern, as outlined in the debate on the second reading, particularly in relation to the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation. The problem we have is that the ambit of the proposed new section has been widened by the amending legislation. By making such amendments, we run the risk of dealing unfairly with those people who may well have properly arranged their affairs in keeping with the original thrust of the statement back in June. It is now, of course, November. This is probably nothing like the worst example of government by Press release. We had in regard to capital gains tax a wait of over a year before we saw the ultimate legislation, which was changed repeatedly before eventually it saw the light of day but which was operative from the date of the Press release.

This matter has been raised many times. It has been alleged by this Government that it is doing no more than the previous Government did, but that is absolute bunkum. The previous Government sought to block clear avoidance practices where they were in clear breach of the intention of existing legislation, or where the requirement to take action was of, say, a changed view of the law by a court. In that instance, one knows the volume of work under which the Australian Taxation Office was put as a result of the previous Government's determination to stamp out those abuses, and let no one pretend that there was no massive effort in that direction. Many of the delays between the Press release and the ultimate legislation in that period flowed from the volume of work required of the Australian Taxation Office by the previous Government to block those abuses. In that situation there was at least some justification for the gap between the Press release and the legislation because there was an attempt to get round the legislation.

Evidently, the purpose of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is to fix up some mistakes. As the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has reported, the Bill will amend the income tax law, and the measures are designed primarily to prevent abuses of the new imputation system of company tax, and changes to the capital gains, superannuation deductions and gift provisions of the income tax law and the taxing arrangements for certain educational allowances. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee draws the attention of the Senate to the following clauses of the Bill. Under the heading `Clauses 38 and 43-Retrospectivity', the Committee says:

Clause 38 of the Bill contains two proposed subclauses (2) and (16) which would have the effect of increasing liability to income tax net retrospectively from two dates. In the case of subclause (2), the date is 4 June 1987; being the date a `draft exposure Bill' was released by the Treasurer. Further, clauses 43 (2) would provide that liability under the proposed clause 42 applies on and after 14th August 1987, the date on which the Treasurer announced the proposed change.

The Committee has drawn attention several times in the past year to the practice of the Taxation Office of making legislation retrospective to the date of the announcement of the proposals to change the law. The only course available to citizens under such provisions is that they should arrange their affairs in accordance with these announcements-or `exposure drafts' of legislation which are intended to allow wide discussion of intended legislative change-rather than in accordance with laws made by the Parliament. Accordingly, the Committee draws clauses 38 and 43 to the attention of the Senate under Principle 1 (a) (1) of the Committee's principles, in that in their retrospective application they may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

That is the matter of principle on which the Opposition is determined to press this amendment. I have a letter from Ernst and Whinney, chartered accountants, who have expressed serious concern about this matter. I quote from the letter:

The most insidious aspect of the Bill is that it will have retroactive effect to those dividends which were paid on or after June 4 of this year. Once again the Government is attempting to legislate by `press release', as it was on June 4 that the Treasurer released the draft Bill and announced the Government's intention to implement this legislation.
The accountants continue:

Some may argue that all taxpayers had notice of the proposed legislation from the date of its effect and, therefore, have not been taken `by surprise'. However, the section in the draft Bill released by the Treasurer on June 4, has been amended considerably by the Bill which was introduced to Parliament on 23rd September and yet it still purports to have retroactive effect from June 4. Accordingly, taxpayers who legitimately arranged the affairs so as not to contravene the proposed Section 46e released in the draft Bill, now find that they have contravened the amended section.
The amendments to the draft Bill released on June 4 are substantive amendments, not simply stylistic or grammatical amendments.
It goes on:
Examples of some of the amendments made to the section by the Bill are:

(i) the draft Bill only applied if the shareholder which received the dividend then proceeded to sell its shares in the asset holding company. The Bill applies if the shareholder which received the dividend or any other person-
I stress the words, `or any other person'-
then proceeded to sell its or his shares in the asset holding company or a company ``related'' to the asset holding company.
(ii) the draft Bill only applied to the disposal of shares after the revaluation of the asset. The Bill applies to a disposal of shares that occurs before the revaluation of the asset.
This is clearly a significant change between the draft and the Bill. Then the accountants continue:

The whole ambit of the section has been dramatically widened by the amendments. Regrettably, the only substantial portion of the section that remains unchanged is the date from which the section has effect.

It would appear that if one of a multiple number of shareholders subsequently sells its shares after an asset revaluation dividend has been paid, all the shareholders will be denied the rebate. Accordingly, an injustice is done to those shareholders which do not sell their shares. Also, because of holding company situations, the `cost' of the rebate being denied may be borne by persons who were not party to the abuse.
