DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Sports Commission-Second Strasbourg Conference on Parliamentary Democracy

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise on the adjournment tonight a matter which goes to the question of what I perceive to be threats made against me in terms of an objection which has been taken to matters arising from the conduct of an Estimates committee hearing. In order to put this matter in perspective, it is necessary to go back very briefly over a couple of matters which arose in the course of the last election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: During the last election campaign the Liberal Party of Australia adopted as a policy, in relation to the promotion of sport in Australia, the abolition of the Australian Sports Commission. We were concerned, among other things, at criticisms which had arisen about the extent of the growth of bureaucracy in sport, and in particular a comment which had appeared in a strategy plan which the Australian Sports Commission had released. Under the heading of `Key Challenges' in that Australian Sports Commission strategy plan the following appeared:
The Commission believes that 3 major issues and concerns within Australian sports today require particular attention. They are:

(i) The level of bureaucracy in sport. Throughout sport in Australia, and particularly within the 3 levels of government, the bureaucracy of sport has grown significantly in recent years. That growth has occurred during a period in which Australian sporting performance, with some exceptions, has been disappointing and declining. The more we have spent on bureaucratic structure the less able, it appears, we have been in producing world class athletes and teams.

Arising from our consideration of a number of these matters, my Party adopted a policy for the abolition of the Australian Sports Commission and, in announcing that policy, the then shadow Minister for Sport, Mr Peter Reith, made some comments about the extent to which he believed that we had not as a nation got value for money out of the Sports Commission and that he believed that the Sports Commission had not really done very much to assist the development of sports in Australia. It appears to me that that is a comment which a person in political activity is perfectly entitled to make, and in particular when advancing a policy for the abolition of a particular body and deciding why that body should be marked for abolition.

Mr Reith's comments apparently upset some members of the Sports Commission and people employed by the Sports Commission. As a result, they issued a statement saying that they regarded the shadow Minister's comments as defamatory and that they proposed to take legal action against him. In fact they did obtain advice from a firm of solicitors and indicated to the shadow Minister that, unless he published certain retractions, they would proceed against him in the courts for a statement alleged to be defamatory.

Mr Reith made it quite clear that his comments were not intended in any way to be defamatory of individuals within the Sports Commission, or indeed of the integrity of people, or to reflect upon the reputations of people associated with the Commission in their personal capacity. No further action was taken, although I hasten to add that Mr Reith was perfectly satisfied that the comments that he had made were in no way defamatory comments and in fact were in no way legally actionable comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be determined somewhere else anyway.

—Indeed, as Senator Peter Baume says, that is a matter which, if required, would have been elsewhere determined. I was interested when it was drawn to my attention that the Sports Commission had decided to get legal advice not from the Australian Government Solicitor but in fact had gone outside to get private legal advice, and that presumably there had been some expenditure of public money in getting that advice. As a result in Estimates Committee F on 8 October I raised this matter with representatives of the Sports Commission, in particular with Mr Hartung, who is the General Manager of the Australian Sports Commission and a person, I add, for whom I have a very high personal regard. I attempted to find from Mr Hartung certain answers. I asked Mr Hartung questions as follows:

—In the course of the election campaign a statement was made by the then Opposition shadow Minister, Mr Reith, about the operation of the Sports Commission. The Chairman indicated that he believed that the statement was defamatory and that he had formed that view on the basis of an opinion which had been sought from the firm of Dawson Waldron. Is that correct?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-That is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who paid for the advice?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-I would have to check precisely how it was paid but I am making the assumption that the Commission paid the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —So during the course of a political dispute in which a member of one political party made some comments about not, as I recall, any individual but a commission, the Commission used public money to obtain a legal opinion that a matter may have been defamatory, and published statements based upon legal opinion which had been paid for out of public money. Who authorised the expenditure?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-There was a meeting of the Commission executive committee at the time, which considered the statements made by the Opposition spokesman, and it was its decision to seek legal advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did it cost?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-I would have to take that question on notice.

Mr Hartung then assured the Committee, and I accepted his assurance, that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) was not personally involved in this matter. I subsequently questioned Mr Hartung as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Commission normally have access to the advice of the Australian Government Solicitor?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-Yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did it not use the Australian Government Solicitor?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-On that occasion there was a discussion by the executive of the Commission which required urgent and immediate attention.
A little later the questioning went as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that the Australian Government Solicitor was not the quickest possible way?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-It was the opinion of the executive committee that the best way to get the best advice on these sorts of matters was to go to the firm of solicitors you mentioned earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you recall any other instances where criticisms have been made of the operation of the Commission, the competence of the Commission or the expenditure arrangements entered into by the Commission, which have caused it to seek legal advice as to whether its commissioners have been collectively or individually defamed?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hartung-I cannot recall any.

Finally, Mr Hartung agreed to take on notice a number of questions about the way in which the meeting was conducted at which it was decided to seek external legal advice and pay out of public moneys for that external legal advice, and who was responsible for making that decision. I must say that I was subsequently satisfied with the information given to me by the Commission in terms of the provision of the data. I thought that the matter was by and large concluded at that stage. However, by letter dated 27 October 1987, Mr A. E. Harris, the Chairman of the Sports Commission, wrote to me directly as follows:
Dear Senator Puplick,

My attention has been drawn to Hansard dated October 8. Therein is reported your cross examination of the General Manager of the Australian Sports Commission, Mr. Hartung in respect of statements made by Mr. Reith about the Sports Commission and subsequent legal action taken by the Sports Commission in relation to those statements by Mr. Reith.
Firstly, let me say that had you enquired of me as Chairman of the Commission as to the matters to which you subjected Mr. Hartung, you would have been given a prompt, factual and courteous response.

As I read the cross-examination, threadneedled through it was the strong suggestion that the action taken by the Commission in respect of the defamatory comments made by Mr. Reith was taken for political reasons and that there was some improper cost to the public. I find this objectionable and there is not a scintilla of evidence to support such a suggestion. The fact is that Mr. Reith, presumably at the taxpayers expense, launched a defamatory attack on the Commission and its members. At a time, as you point out in your cross-examination of an Election.
There are two things I want to say to you, Senator Puplick, and I want you to be quite clear about them.

Firstly, any time anybody defames myself or any organisation with which I have an association, I will pursue my legal rights as I see fit. Secondly, I am meticulous in my public duties to ensure that there is no politicisation of them, whatsoever.

Mr. Hartung, in due course, will do as you have requested of him, namely answer your questions. I, in due course, will make enquiries as to the cost to the public of this cross-examination and when I receive this information I will determine what further action I propose to take.

One thing I will be doing is sending a copy of this letter to Mr. John Valder in his capacity as President of the Liberal Party with some appropriate comments. In fact, I will attach a copy of the letter to Mr. Valder for your information.
The letter to Mr Valder reads:
Dear John,

I am attaching hereto a letter I have sent to Senator Puplick. You will readily perceive that I find his innuendos not only false but insulting. In fact, if they were said outside of the Parliament, I would probably pursue him legally for defamation.

This kind of behaviour is becoming progressively more objectionable to the Australian public. It is certainly objectionable to those who are requested, from time to time, to give their personal and financial support.

The job of raising money for politicians I know has always been difficult. It becomes that much more difficult when people prostitute the system. What is implicit in the cross-examination of a public servant by Senator Puplick is frankly beyond the pale of reason and, as an Australian, I have no intention of tolerating this kind of behaviour by politicians misusing their position of privilege.
Look forward to seeing you soon. With warmest personal regards.
Yours sincerely,
Ted

These letters from Mr Harris, both the one addressed to me and the one addressed to the then President of my Party, are clearly intended to be threatening and intimidatory of me in a personal sense, in terms of the threat to pursue me legally if I persist with what is alleged to be some sort of cross-examination which took place during the Estimates Committee hearing. This is also an attempt to threaten me by enclosing a letter addressed to the then Federal President of my Party, in effect saying `If Senator Puplick continues to behave in this fashion, do not look to us, to me or to my company for any financial support for your political party', with the phrase `The job of raising money for politicians I know has always been difficult'.

In terms of Mr Harris's original letter, firstly, it asserts certain things which may or may not be true; that is to say, that Mr Reith's original statements were defamatory. That matter has not been settled and there is no way in which it could be settled except for the matter to have proceeded to court. Secondly, it asserts that Mr Hartung was subjected to some sort of cross-examination. I suppose whatever term one chooses to use about the robust exchanges which take place from time to time in Estimates committees, they may be put down as cross-examination. I presume that in fact is part of the ongoing process for which Estimates committees were properly established. Thirdly, Mr Harris says, `If you had enquired of me . . .'. Mr Harris was not a witness before the Estimates Committee. Had he been a witness, I would have inquired of him. Mr Hartung happened to be the senior person there. Mr Harris suggests that there was some improper cost to the public being asserted by myself. What I was trying to find out was whether there was a cost to the public, why was the Australian Government Solicitor not used, why was the external legal advice sought, and what was the cost of it. Mr Harris alleges that Mr Reith made a defamatory attack upon the Commission, to which I have already referred, and that that was done `at the taxpayers' expense'. I am at a loss to understand where additional expense to the taxpayer arises as far as that is concerned. Mr Reith made a statement, in his capacity as the shadow Minister. I am not aware that there was any cost to the taxpayer in that particular exercise.

Then Mr Harris went on to say `if anybody defames myself'. He was in no way defamed by anybody, and I think that is quite clear. He then says that he will in due course `make enquiries as to the cost to the public of this cross-examination and when I receive this information I will determine what further action I propose to take'. Mr Harris is perfectly entitled to take whatever action he thinks appropriate, but he will in fact find that costs to the taxpayer of Mr Hartung answering questions at the Senate Estimates Committee are part of the normal procedures of the operations of Estimates committees. I am sure that Mr Harris is in a position to determine what further action he proposes to take.

I have not had an opportunity to consult Mr Valder, although I did try to get hold of him since the receipt of this particular letter. I have no doubt that he would be singularly unimpressed receiving a letter which in fact makes it basically plain that the purpose of the letter is to say to the Federal President of a political party: `If one of the members of your political party, properly exercising his responsibilities as a member of an Estimates committee, chooses to use that forum to seek information, and implicitly to make criticism of the way in which a commission with which I, as an individual, am associated, and continues to act in that fashion, you, Mr Federal President, should be on notice that there is perhaps some financial downside for your party in allowing that sort of examination to continue without control or in an unchecked fashion'.

I do not know whether that sort of letter-either the one addressed to me or the one addressed to Mr Valder-in fact constitutes a breach of privilege. I am frankly not overly concerned whether it does or does not. What I do want to put on the record clearly is this. I think that during my participation in Estimates committees-and Senator Richardson, who is in the chamber this evening, was present as the Minister on duty during the conduct of the Estimates committees this year-I have established that I am fairly vigorous in the questions that I ask and in the information which I pursue. The information which I have sought I believe is information sought properly in the discharge of my public duties and public responsibilities. I am certainly not going to be intimidated by Mr Harris, whoever he is, whoever he thinks he is and whoever he purports to be in these things, not to ask the questions which I think are appropriate to be asked. Indeed, when the material from the Estimates committee, which I sought, is supplied to the Senate, the full details will be available and on the public record. They will demonstrate when the meeting about which I sought information was held, who was present at the meeting, what the cost of the legal advice sought was, who authorised the expenditure, what was the item against which the expenditure was charged, and whether in fact there was any consultation between the Commission and the Minister. On that matter, as I say, I have accepted the assurance given by Mr Hartung that the Minister was in no way involved in that exercise, and I do not think that has ever been a matter which I have sought in any way to question or to query.

As far as this particular matter is concerned, I want to make it perfectly clear that I am not capable of being intimidated in this fashion, nor do I believe that attempts to intimidate in this fashion should pass without being put upon the public record. I have certainly attempted to do that this evening; I believe I have done it in a reasonably dispassionate form. But I put both Mr Harris and anybody else clearly on notice that I am not-nor do I believe is any senator on either side-capable of being dissuaded from pursuing the correct method of obtaining information about the expenditure of public moneys by the threats, direct or implied, whichever one may wish to see, which I believe are quite clear in Mr Harris's correspondence both to me and to the then Federal President of my Party. I certainly do not intend in any way to be diverted from my course of pursuing what I see to be my proper public responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief in response to Senator Puplick's comments about the conduct of Estimates Committee F, the reply that he received from Mr Harris and the letter that Mr Harris forwarded to John Valder. As Senator Puplick correctly stated, the Commission did seek legal advice from Dawson Waldron, and I believe that the Estimates Committee has tonight been handed some answers on that matter. It is a matter, I suppose, for Mr Harris to then determine, on the basis of his reading of the transcript, what he would consider matters of manner, taste or tone and to act accordingly. TALK.START.PARA: —Some Ministers try.

—That is often for a different reason, and always for a better purpose. However, as I said, I regret that the matter has gotten this far. I hope that over time Mr Harris will cool his passions and Senator Puplick will not feel too intimidated-although, knowing Senator Puplick, I suspect that it would take rather more than those two letters to have him not ask the questions he wishes to ask the next time around.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I would say that if whatever Senator Puplick has done causes a company the size of Ampol not to give donations to the Liberal Party, I am delighted. I would have to say, however, that, as far as the Government is concerned and as far as all senators are concerned, the way that Estimates committees are run will not be affected by the letter, and I hope that on the morrow the matter will all be forgotten.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Treatment of Veteran by Clinical Psychologist

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the case of a patient whose reference number was MSS 6227 did the Department of Veterans' Affairs NSW Branch Office notify Mr Petroni (Clinical Psychologist), on 12 December 1986, that although he had been given approval for 6 sessions of treatment from 27 November 1984, as this number had been exceeded, payment for any further sessions was declined unless prior approval was obtained.

(2) Did Mr Petroni advise the branch office on 27 February 1987 that his secretary had obtained approval for 6 more sessions, and again, later, for another 6; if so, how can this be reconciled with the statement by the Branch referred to in (1) above.
(3) Did Mr Petroni first see this client on 25 July 1984 and was the first payment not made until 12 December 1984; if so, what was the reason for this delay.
(4) Why were accounts for sessions over the period of treatment paid at apparently inconsistent rates, and exactly what rate of payment for each session was made.

(5) How many sessions were paid for by the Department at the rate of $38 per visit; did the Department regard these as overpayments; has any action been taken to recover any part of these payments, as overpayments; and who made the decision not to reclaim all or part of any alleged overpayment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. Although Mr Petroni conveyed this advice, there is no record of any request or approval having been given for other than the first six sessions.

(3) The first payment to Mr Petroni for treatment received by the patient in question was made on 30 November 1984. The delay in payment was due to time taken to investigate Mr Petroni's accounts and staff shortages.

(4) All payments should have been made at the rates set by the Inter-Departmental Committee on Fees and Allowances. Most accounts were paid at the departmental rate of $37.50 for the initial consultation, $18.80 for each subsequent visit and $15 for a tape. Six sessions were paid at the incorrect rate of $38 per visit.

(5) Six sessions were incorrectly paid at the rate claimed by Mr Petroni at $38 per visit. Mr Petroni was incorrectly advised that the amount overpaid would not be recovered. The Deputy Commissioner, New South Wales, has been instructed to pursue recovery.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Wilco Electrical Pty Ltd: Industrial Dispute

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1987 (Hansard, page 224), Senator Lewis asked me as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that strike action in Victoria by members of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union in defiance of recommendations by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has forced Wilco Electrical Pty Ltd-a Victorian manufacturer of sophisticated electrical equipment for local and export markets-to close down its Abbotsford factory in Melbourne and that now bans have been placed on its Notting Hill factory? Is the Minister further aware that pickets imposed at the plant at Abbotsford are being used to prevent the company from moving equipment from Abbotsford, even though this equipment is crucial to the continued operation of the company's plant at Notting Hill where 220 people are employed? Does not this kind of industrial action, which is placing in jeopardy the ability of a high-tech Australian manufacturer to compete in world markets, make a mockery of the rhetoric in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) document Australia Reconstructed? What action has the Government taken or will it take to bring these unionists to their senses?
In my reply, I undertook to refer the question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has provided the following response:

The Government is aware of recent industrial action against Wilco Electrical Pty Ltd and of the company's closure of its Abbotsford plant. I understand that Wilco announced in February 1987 that it intended to close the Abbotsford plant and relocate those operations at its Notting Hill plant. The industrial action centred on unresolved issues associated with the decision to close the plant and, as such, was not the direct cause of the closure as suggested by Senator Lewis. The Government is also aware that pickets were established at the Abbotsford plant and that the then employees at the plant continued strike action despite recommendations by Mr Commissioner Peterson of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that they return to work. The Government does not condone those actions, indeed it is our strong view that compliance with recommendations of the Commission is essential for the effective operation of dispute settlement mechanisms.
I understand that Wilco and the unions involved have been able to reach agreement on the issues in dispute and that the picket was lifted on 18 September 1987.
